The company, Germany's second-largest chemical maker, said third-quarter profit jumped to 906 million marks ($638 million), lifting nine-month pretax profit 39 percent above the period a year ago, to 3.3 billion marks.          "The fourth quarter might not be so good as last year," the chief executive, Manfred Schneider, said, adding that it "would be a success" if the 1995 full-year profit level could be maintained in 1996. Nonetheless, Mr. Schneider said that an increase in the dividend still made sense. Shareholders received 13 marks a share last year, and Mr. Schneider indicated that the payout could reach 14 marks soon.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: A Long March to Capitalism
abstract: Not long ago, Tsingtao Brewery looked unbeatable.         With a high quality product, a well established name, a booming beer market and ambitious plans to quadruple production in five years, Tsingtao seemed perfectly positioned to ride China's locomotive-like economic growth. In 1993, when the Government allowed China's top companies to list shares on Hong Kong's  stock exchange, Tsingtao was chosen to go first, and its stock was one of the hottest issues of the year.

headline: Poland's President-Elect, Under a Cloud, Pledges to Be Impartial
abstract: In a conciliatory move intended to heal deep political and emotional rifts after Poland's elections, President-elect Aleksander Kwasniewski resigned today  from the political organization he created six years ago on the ashes of the Communist Party.         As he handed in his membership card, No. 13, he told applauding supporters of the Social Democracy Party that he wanted there to be no doubt about his ability to treat all Poles in an "equal way."

headline: Novell to Sell Wordperfect Software Line
abstract: Novell Inc. said today that it intended to sell its struggling Wordperfect line of software applications, which it acquired only 18 months ago in an $855 million stock swap.         Novell said it was holding discussions with several companies and expected to close a sale by the end of January.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TOYOTA PLANS TO BUILD NEW TRUCK PLANT IN INDIANA
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation formally announced yesterday that it would invest $700 million to build a new truck assembly plant in Princeton, Ind., that will begin production in the fall of 1998. As expected, the plant would directly employ about 1,300 people who would build about 100,000 T100 full-size pickup trucks a year. The company has chosen a 1,100-acre site in Gibson County, 21 miles north of Evansville, for the facility. The new plant would be the Japanese auto maker's fourth vehicle manufacturing facility in North America. State and local officials said that they would provide Toyota an incentive package worth about $72 million, including $29.8 million from the state and $42  million from local sources.

headline: Major Goes to Ulster and Ireland For Support of the Peace Plan
abstract: Prime Minister John Major campaigned in both parts of the island today, seeking support for Britain's position on the Northern Ireland peace effort, which has been weakened by a resurgence of vigilante killings widely attributed  to the I.R.A.         Mr. Major, visiting Belfast and other areas in Northern Ireland as well as Dublin, arrived during the busiest week in years in the official effort to produce full-fledged peace negotiations.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Company Wins Second Asbestos Case
abstract: Shares in the British engineering company T & N P.L.C. rose sharply yesterday in London on news that the company had won a United States asbestos case brought by The Chase Manhattan Bank. Shares in the company rose 21 percent, adding 35 pence, to 165. On Thursday the stock gained 8.3 percent after T & N settled a separate dispute with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over asbestos contamination.          On Thursday a New York jury dismissed a $185 million claim by Chase over the use of asbestos in the construction of its New York headquarters in 1959. Chase  had contended that T & N was aware of the dangers of asbestos at the time.   (AP)

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;4 Guilty of Distributing H.I.V.-Infected Blood
abstract: A German court today found three company officials and a laboratory technician guilty of distributing inadequately tested blood products that infected at least three people with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Two of the three have died, prosecutors said.         The case, in Koblenz, arose from disclosures two years ago that plasma tainted with H.I.V. had been distributed to scores of hospitals. The negligence  charges relate to 71,302 batches of plasma distributed to more than 50 hospitals.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lintas Worldwide To Be Renamed
abstract: Lintas Worldwide, one of the three large agency networks owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, will be renamed Ammirati Puris Lintas, effective on Feb. 1. The announcement came 17 months after Interpublic bought Ammirati & Puris, a creatively focused midsize agency in New York, and merged it with the New York office of Lintas. The Lintas offices in New York and London have been called Ammirati & Puris/ Lintas; that name will be adopted, minus the ampersand and slash, at all 155 Lintas offices in 58 countries.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;STANDARD FEDERAL BANK TO BUY BELL BANCORP
abstract: Standard Federal Bank agreed yesterday to acquire Bell Bancorp Inc. for $37.50 a share in cash, plus payments related to outstanding stock options, in a transaction valued at about $354.1 million. Bell Bancorp is the parent of Bell Federal Savings and Loan Association, based in Chicago. Bell has total assets of $1.9 billion and $1.6 billion in deposits. Standard Federal, which is based in Troy, Mich., had assets of $13.3 billion and deposits of $9.1 billion.

headline: Clinton Gets Wary Backing From His Rival, Dole
abstract: Only hours before President Clinton departed for the signing of the Bosnian peace agreement in Paris, Senator Bob Dole sought to ease his mission. He reached back 25 years in history and recalled the furious Senate debates over the Vietnam War and the issue of supporting American troops and their Commander  in Chief.         The Kansas Republican and Senate majority leader presented one of the more arresting moments in the inevitable overlap of foreign policy and domestic politics: Mr. Dole, the scarred war hero, considered the front-runner to challenge Mr. Clinton in 1996, offering wary backing to a President regularly dogged for not serving in Vietnam.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Long Bond Tumbles After Report
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, on a stronger-than-expected Government report of durable goods orders in September, and continuing concern about the effects of drawn-out budget negotiations.         The traders' underlying fear was that a delay in a budget accord would also stall an expected cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve next month, maybe even endanger the chance of a cut at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in December. Few in the market are worried that the Government will default on its debt if an accord is not reached in time.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Soybeans Up on Drought Fears
abstract: Soybean prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as concern grew that a lack of rain was harming Brazil's crop, the world's second largest.         Wheat prices also rose strongly on concerns over low rainfall. The Commodity  Research Bureau index of 21 commodities gained 1.03 points, to 244.09.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Republicans Carping At Communications Bill Disgruntled House Republicans were taking pot shots at deals negotiated by their own leadership to overhaul the nation's communications laws just a day after House and Senate negotiators said they had reached agreement on a bill.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Economic Data Spur Treasuries
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday in response to weaker-than-expected economic reports, particularly for housing.         The market was given a lift in the afternoon by an interview with a Federal Reserve Governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, who told the Market News Service that he  felt "inclined" to ease credit further, although not necessarily right away. "As inflation comes down and we get a resolution of fiscal policy, I'm inclined  that way," he said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Dorney Park and Wildwater Kingdom, Allentown, Pa., owned by Cedar Fair L.P., to  Tierney & Partners, Philadelphia, a unit of True North Communications, to handle its account, previously at Marc Advertising, Pittsburgh. The billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Air New Zealand Moves Into Australian Market
abstract: Air New Zealand Ltd. has gained a foothold in the Australian aviation market  by buying a 25 percent stake in Ansett Australia Holdings Ltd. from the Australian transportation company TNT Ltd. for $200 million (Australian), or $148 million (United States). Air New Zealand has also agreed to take an option  to buy TNT's remaining 25 percent stake for $225 million (Australian). The option must be exercised by Feb. 15, 1998.          Air New Zealand has held a marathon series of talks with Ansett's two 50 percent shareholders: TNT and the News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch. The talks with the News Corporation broke down earlier this year.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: World News Briefs;Britain Tightens Rules On Pollution Emissions
abstract: Tough new standards on air pollution were announced today by the British Government in an effort to cut emissions of particulates to a third of those allowed in the United States.         Particulates are tiny particles carried in the air from diesel exhausts and domestic heating, and they can kill people who are already suffering from lung diseases.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MOODY'S INDICATES RATINGS ON $1 BILLION OF ISSUES
abstract: Moody's Investors Service will give the Kmart Corporation's proposed issue of $1 billion worth of new stock and bonds an investment-grade rating for one class of securities, and ratings below investment grade for two others, if the struggling retailer goes through with the sale. The ratings are still subject to a possible downgrade, Moody's said this week. The credit-rating agency's move came a week after Kmart reached an agreement to immediately pay back $548 million of its real estate debt if its credit rating should fall below investment grade, or to "junk" status. Mary Lorencz, a spokeswoman for Kmart, which is based in Troy, Mich., declined to comment yesterday on the latest rating.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Mannington Resilient Floors, Salem, N.J., a division of Mannington Mills Inc., to Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, to handle its account, previously at the Weightman Group, Philadelphia. The billings were estimated at $10 million. Golden Pacific Brewing Co., Emeryville, Calif., to Zuckerman/Fernades & Partners, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the microbrewery, which was previously handled in-house. The billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: MONDAY Lubys Cafeterias Inc Phillips Pete Co TUESDAY Enron Corp Hannaford Bros Co Hillenbrand Inds Inc Puget Sound Pwr&Lt Co Rite Aid Corp Sprint Corp WEDNESDAY AAR Corp Bard C R Inc CBI Inds Inc CSX Corp National Health Invs Shelby Williams Inds Walgreen Co Weyerhaeuser Co THURSDAY Reliastar Finl Corp Santa Fe Pac Pipeline WPS Res Corp FRIDAY Mercury Fin Co New York St Elc&Gas Union Elec Co Unum Corp SATURDAY Tanger Factory Outlet

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Investors Complete Deal To Buy Canary Wharf
abstract: A consortium of North American, Swiss and Middle East investors completed their purchase of the giant Canary Wharf complex in London yesterday. The completion of the deal was announced by Lloyds Bank, the leader of a group of bank lenders that owned the property. The price was not disclosed. The deal was  first announced Oct. 2.          The consortium, known as the International Property Corporation, is led by the Canadian developer Paul Reichmann and includes Prince al-Waleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia; the Swiss banker Edmond Safra; the CNA Financial Corporation, a unit of Laurence A. Tisch's Loews Corporation, and Mutual Series Fund Inc., which is managed by Michael Price. Mr. Reichmann's company, Olympia & York, built Canary Wharf in the 1980's only to lose it to bank lenders in 1992. (AP)

headline: Russian Seizes 27 Koreans In Moscow
abstract: Firing into the air, Russian commandos swarmed onto a tour bus near the Kremlin early today, freeing four South Koreans and a Russian driver who had been held hostage for 10 hours by a rifle-carrying gunman. The gunman died in the attack.         About 20 commandos attacked the bus before dawn, unleashing a barrage of gunfire and tossing stun grenades that exploded with searing flashes.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Donald F. Brown, vice president at Time Inc., Tokyo, who oversees the operating  divisions in Japan, Korea and Taiwan, was named to the new position of president of Time Canada, Toronto. Both units are owned by Time Warner Inc.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NEUBERGER & BERMAN STUDIES PARTNERSHIP SALE
abstract: Neuberger & Berman L.P. is considering a plan to sell all or part of its $36  billion money-management partnership, the company said yesterday. Neuberger & Berman, which oversees money for mutual funds, pension funds and wealthy investors, hired investment bankers from Goldman, Sachs & Company and Putnam, Lovell & Thornton Inc. to help the company decide how to proceed, said Lawrence  Zicklin, managing partner of the closely held firm. The 56-year-old firm might be worth as much as $700 million, or 2 percent of assets, if it was sold outright, according to The Wall Street Journal, which first reported Neuberger & Berman's plan.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;4 Nigerian Activists Arrested and Released
abstract: Four campaigners for democracy have been arrested in Nigeria, but were released on bail, newspapers reported today.         Pressure on Nigeria's military rulers to restore democracy has increased since last month, when they executed nine minority rights activists despite appeals from around the world.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pechiney Stock Falls As Swap Plan Falters
abstract: Shares in Pechiney International S.A. plunged as much as 10 percent during the day yesterday as investors abandoned the idea of swapping their shares for stock in the parent company, Pechiney S.A., and sold them instead. Pechiney International stock recovered by the close, ending down 1.5 French francs at 89.5 francs ($18.27). The stock had fallen as much as 9 francs, or 10 percent, to 82 francs ($16.73).          "Pechiney is at such a low price that it's better to sell now," said Laurent Mace, a trader at Nomura Bourse. Pechiney S.A. shares fell to a 52-week low of 169.7 francs, down 0.3 franc from Friday, a 9.3 percent drop from the 187 francs of the French Government's public offering a week ago. France sold most of its 56 percent stake in Pechiney then.  The offer of 5 Pechiney S.A. shares for 9 Pechiney International shares ends Jan. 9, said the Paris brokerage firm Transbourse. (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Ottawa Moves Quickly in Effort to Mollify Quebec
abstract: Jarred by the narrow defeat of the Quebec independence referendum, Canadian leaders today promised quick action aimed at meeting the restive province's demands for greater autonomy.         But some Canadians said the moves came too late to contain the separatist anger that has taken hold in Quebec.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Alberto-Culver And BBDO to Part
abstract: The Alberto-Culver Company said yesterday that after a decade it had agreed to part company with BBDO Chicago, a unit of the Omnicom Group that has handled  accounts like VO5 hair-care products, Molly McButter seasoning and Static Guard  spray. The billings were estimated at $12 million.          Dan Stone, a spokesman for Alberto-Culver in Melrose Park, Ill., confirmed a report of the change this week in Adweek, adding that the company was deciding whether to conduct a review or reassign the brands to one of the other agencies  it uses. They are Lois/U.S.A. and E. Morris Communications in Chicago and Partners & Shevack in New York.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Developments in U.S. Neighbors Cause Dollar to Rise, Then Dip
abstract: The dollar ended little changed against most leading currencies yesterday. It initially rose to a five-week high against the yen as traders assessed the United States impact of the vote in Quebec that narrowly rejected secession from Canada, but the dollar then slipped back after the Mexican peso weakened.         "Canada helped the dollar, and Mexico held it back," said Jay Westheimer, senior currency trader with Banco di Sicilia in New York.

headline: Yield on 30-Year Bond Falls to 6.30%, Lowest Since Early 1994
abstract: The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped to 6.30 percent yesterday, returning to its level before the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates in February 1994.         This lower yield -- nearly two percentage points below where it was last November -- comes amid growing optimism among market participants that the economy continues to show steady growth without accelerating inflation. In addition, there is still hope that the Clinton Administration and Congress can reach a budget compromise without either shutting down the Government when the Federal borrowing ceiling is reached shortly or defaulting on the Government's debt obligations.

headline: Ex-Foreign Minister Jailed in Cambodia
abstract: The former Foreign Minister of Cambodia and a prominent critic of Cambodia's  current Government, Prince Norodom Sirivudh, was jailed today on charges that he had plotted to kill one of Cambodia's two Prime Ministers.         The Prince, a half-brother of King Norodom Sihanouk and a member of Parliament, was taken from his home in Phnom Penh, the capital, after telling reporters that he had turned down a deal that would have allowed him to leave his war-shattered nation.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Soars Past 4,900; S.& P. 500 Sets Record The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 4,900 for the first time, and the  Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a record. Benign news on last month's inflation rate put traders in a buying mood.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Striking Newspaper Workers Out in Cold in a Union Town
abstract: Nearly four months into a newspaper strike here, the companies that own this  city's two daily papers appear to be defeating their unions.         Here, in the city that is sometimes called the labor capital of the country,  the papers have published a newspaper every day since the strike began on July 13. Since September, the two papers have each been publishing their usual separate daily editions.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PART OF BELGIAN PHONE COMPANY IS PRIVATIZED
abstract: A consortium headed by the Ameritech Corporation won a 49.9 percent stake yesterday in the Belgian state-owned telephone company Belgacom with a $2.5 billion bid. The Belgian Telecommunications Minister, Elio di Rupo, said the bid from Ameritech and partners from Singapore and Denmark beat a rival offer for the stake from a Dutch-Swiss consortium. The Ameritech offer was chosen unanimously by the state privatization commission and by Belgacom itself. Within the Belgacom consortium, Ameritech has a 35 percent share; Tele Danmark A.S. 33 percent; Singapore Telecommunications Ltd. 27 percent, and a group of institutional partners 5 percent.

headline: Paul Eddington, 68, Star of 'Yes, Prime Minister'
abstract: Paul Eddington, an actor who gained attention on both sides of the Atlantic as the star of the satirical British television sitcoms "Yes, Minister" and "Yes, Prime Minister," died on Saturday at his home in London. He was 68.         The cause was cancer, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Cellular Provider Sues Telefonos de Mexico
abstract: Grupo Iusacell S.A., a big Mexican cellular-phone company, sued Telefonos de  Mexico today, accusing the huge state phone-service provider of illegal business practices.         Iusacell filed the lawsuit with the Federal Competition Commission, contending that Telmex, as it is widely known, illegally subsidizes the business operations of its cellular division, Radio Movil Dipsa S.A., or Telcel, with revenue from its domestic telephone business.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;No Welfare for Arms Merchants
abstract: DESPITE its pledge to work diligently toward a balanced budget by 2002, Congress has shamelessly loaded up this year's military budget with wasteful projects that have more to do with defending the flow of funds to key constituencies than with defending the country from potential adversaries. But there is one program that has been quietly created in the name of national defense that may do more damage than all the others: an open-ended, multibillion-dollar plan to provide Government-guaranteed loans for weapons exports.        Ever since the news this summer that France had surpassed the United States in the dubious race to be the leading arms supplier to the third world, United States arms merchants have been pleading for a handout. Seizing on France's banner sales to press the case for a Government-backed arms export guarantee fund, Joel Johnson of the Aerospace Industries Association asserted, "We're not  asking for a lot."

headline: Economic Scene;Why is a rich country down in the dumps, if it is?
abstract: IF the economy is up, why is America down? That question certainly interests  President Clinton, who is planning to lead the nation from its funk (assuming it's in one). But it is also the title of the cover article in the October issue of The Atlantic Monthly, the work of three researchers at a left-of-center think tank in San Francisco called Redefining Progress.         The article will no doubt be dismissed by some as a familiar critique of the  ways professional bean counters mismeasure economic progress by focusing so intently on the gross domestic product, a barometer designed to measure the total output of goods and services produced by the economy. And in this case, the critique is also spiced with just a pinch of paranoia. But the core of the argument -- that traditional income accounting offers at best an incomplete index of national welfare -- deserves a close look.

headline: Fog Besieges U.S. Operation in Bosnia for 4th Day
abstract: Once again, weather defeated the American peacekeeping operation in Bosnia, with planes unable to land at the airport here for the fourth consecutive day because of heavy fog.         They could be heard but not seen from the ground as they made futile passes over the runway.

headline: London Journal;As 15 Million Watch, Diana Relives Painful Years
abstract: The failed marriage of the Prince and Princess of Wales has finally reached the modern celebrity age: both parties have gone on television to give their side of the story.         Tonight, in an extraordinarily candid interview that the British Broadcasting Corporation estimated had been watched by 15 million people in Britain, Diana, the estranged wife of Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, described  herself as being so beaten down by her loveless marriage that she sought refuge  in self-mutilation and "rampant bulimia."

headline: Citibank in St. Petersburg
abstract: Citibank's Russian unit said on Friday that it would open an office in St. Petersburg, Russia's second-largest city, in January. William R. Rhodes, Citibank deputy chairman, said the bank would have a full range of banking services, excluding handling private accounts.

headline: Orders for Computer Chips Fall Along With Book-to-Bill Ratio
abstract: New orders for computer chips declined in November, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today, indicating that demand could be slowing.         The trade group's book-to-bill ratio, a closely watched gauge of demand for computer chips, fell to 1.14 in November from 1.18 in October.

headline: Liz Claiborne Narrows Review
abstract: Liz Claiborne Inc. in New York has narrowed the review on the creative portion of the account of its Liz Claiborne and Elisabeth branded apparel and accessories lines to 4 agencies from 10. The account had been handled by Altschiller & Company in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, for the last eight years until Altschiller and Claiborne parted ways in March. At that time, Claiborne billings totaled about $8 million; the company now says they will increase to $20 million to $25 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bond Yield Falls to 6.32% On Hopes of a Rate Cut  Treasury yields tumbled, as credit market traders renewed hopes of an interest-rate cut soon. Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, propelled the market when he said that interest rates were excessive for the long term, and that the Fed should begin to lower them, but not necessarily "imminently." The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.32 percent, from 6.39 percent.  [ Page D18. ] Stock averages advanced, led by large-capitalization and transportation issues. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 28.18 points, to 4,783.66. The transportation index had its best day since July.  [ D8. ]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: H. F. AHMANSON & CO., Irwindale, Calif., a bank holding company, authorized a $250 million stock buyback program. At current prices, the buyback plan represents about 10 million shares, or 8.5 percent of the company's 117 million shares outstanding. WESTERN AUTO SUPPLY CO., Kansas City, Mo., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co., has won a bidding war for most of Nationwide Automotive Inc.'s stores. Western Auto offered $17.6 million for 84 of 132 outlets and all of its warehouse inventory.

headline: Prudential Shift on Insurance Commissions
abstract: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has changed the way it pays agents to sell some new policies, a move that analysts say may be a first step toward curbing deceptive industry sales practices.   Prudential, the largest United States life insurer, said today that the new commissions spread payments to agents fairly evenly over the life of policies worth at least $1 million. That differs from the typical system of large initial payments that regulators say prompts agents to push costly, unneeded coverage.

headline: Central Asia Boeing Deal
abstract: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had received orders for five new airplanes from the central Asian nations of Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. Uzbekistan Airways ordered two 767-300's and one 757-200. The $258 million purchase is the first for the former Soviet republic. The National Civil Aviation Authority of Turkmenistan ordered two 757-200's for $123 million. Boeing said the orders could be the first of many from the nations formed after the breakup of the Soviet Union. (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Royal Nedlloyd Reports 47% Drop in Profit
abstract: The Dutch transport company Royal Nedlloyd Group N.V. said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 47 percent as the strength of the guilder offset revenue gains and the company's ocean shipping division lost business. Nedlloyd, one of Europe's largest sea and land transport companies, earned 23 million guilders ($14.3 million) in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, down from 43 million guilders in the comparable period a year ago.          The company said it expected its full-year profit before one-time charges to be about 53 million guilders ($33 million), or half of last year's profit. Nedlloyd said it would take a substantial one-time charge in the final quarter to cover "serious irregularities" at its Nedlloyd Road Cargo unit in Austria.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: Intuit Plans a Financial Service on Internet
abstract: Intuit Inc. plans to set up a financial service on the Internet, using technology from the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Concentric Network Corporation.   Customers will be able to use Quicken 96, the updated version of the company's flagship banking software, to get free access to the company's Internet site. The Quicken Financial Network will offer product information, personal finance advice and direct connections to Intuit's financial partners.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; Can a Mutual Fund Learn a Way of Life?
abstract: A LIFE-STYLE fund sounds like a line item in Ivana Trump's divorce decree. It suggests a pool of money that lets you live in the manner to which you wish to become accustomed, perhaps as a globe-trotting playboy, a Park Avenue socialite or a literary recluse.  But this new type of mutual fund is being bought by thousands of ordinary Americans -- primarily in 401(k) retirement accounts -- in hopes that it will allow them to maintain their existing life styles when they stop working.

headline: Stocks Fall in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading lower here this morning. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 247.51 points, or 1.34 percent, at 18,258.77. On Friday, the Nikkei rose 285.87 points, or 1.57 percent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Home and Garden Television, Knoxville, Tenn., a unit of the E. W. Scripps Co., to Lewis Advertising, Birmingham, Ala., to handle its account, previously handled by various agencies on a project basis. The billings have not been determined.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HUMANA WINS $3.8 BILLION MILITARY CONTRACT
abstract: Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., has received a $3.8 billion contract to provide health care to families of members of the military in the Southeastern United States, the Defense Department said yesterday. The company's Military Healthcare Services division will provide health care in Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Tennessee, South Carolina and part of Louisiana, starting  on May 1. If the Pentagon exercises all options under the contract, the arrangement will run until May 2001. The announcement was made after Humana's stock closed at $24.75, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Scott Paper in India Deal
abstract: The Scott Paper Company said today that it had formed a joint venture with Pudumjee Agro Industries to produce and market Scott Paper's tissue products in India. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Scott Paper, based in Boca Raton, Fla., said it would be the majority owner. The venture will begin in the fourth quarter. Pudumjee Agro is India's sole producer of tissue paper.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SYNTELLECT INC., Phoenix, which supplies interactive voice response systems, agreed to acquire Pinnacle Investment Associates Inc., for stock valued at about $16.5 million. Syntellect will exchange 1.15 shares of its stock for each Pinnacle share.

headline: From the Golan Heights, Peace Appears Far Away
abstract: Here in the shadow of the Golan, Hala Mutab Abo Saleh is waiting for the day  when the soaring heights captured by Israel 28 years ago will become Syrian again.         A year ago it seemed possible to the 58-year-old woman and her neighbors that that dawn might be near. But on surrounding mountaintops, Israeli posts stand as commanding as ever, and across the rocky volcanic soil, Syria's southwest corner, the feelings now expressed are those of a bitter resolve.

headline: 702 Register to Run For Palestinian Seats
abstract: Seven hundred people have registered as candidates for council seats in the first Palestinian national elections, but only two -- Yasir Arafat and the leader of a charity group -- will run for the top executive position, the director of the Central Elections Committee said today.         Mahmoud Abbas, the director of the committee, said that by Sunday, the last day for candidate registration, "Only two people had registered for presidential elections and 700 for the council."

headline: S.E.C. Planning Action on Denver Bonds
abstract: In a move that could set a significant precedent, the Securities and Exchange Commission has informed Denver officials that it plans to bring an enforcement action against them over the sale of bonds to finance the city's new airport.   Denver's city attorney, Daniel Muse, said yesterday that the city and county of Denver had received so-called Wells notices in which the S.E.C. indicated that it would bring an administrative enforcement action unless Denver officials could provide a compelling reason to stop it.

headline: Nordic Track Picks Draft Direct
abstract: Nordic Track Inc. in Chaska, Minn., the marketer of fitness equipment and accessories, has selected Draft Direct Worldwide in Chicago to handle its consolidated account, which was previously handled by various agencies on a project basis. The billings were estimated at $50 million.

headline: SFX to Buy 5 Stations
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said this week that it planned to buy five North Carolina radio stations and had an option to buy a sixth from an affiliate of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. for a total price of $39 million. SFX, based in New York, will acquire WTRG-FM and WRDU-FM of Raleigh for $28 million, and WWWB-AM, WMFR-AM and WMAG-FM of Greensboro for $6 million.

headline: A Poster Child for I.R.S. Foes
abstract: It is more than six years since two dozen I.R.S. agents stormed into the Irvine, Calif., headquarters of the Amcor Capital Corporation, armed with guns, a search warrant and a firm belief that they had uncovered a vast criminal conspiracy responsible for up to $1 billion in fraudulent deductions.   But if there ever was a huge conspiracy at Amcor, once the nation's biggest seller of agricultural tax shelters, the Internal Revenue Service gave up trying to find it a long time ago, and no indictments ever resulted.

headline: Reynolds Metals Account in Review
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company, the maker of Reynolds aluminum and plastic wraps, said yesterday that it had placed in review its account, which has been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York for the last 23 years. The billings were estimated at $15 million.   Joe Vagi, a spokesman for Reynolds in Richmond, confirmed a report of the review this week in Adweek, adding that William M. Weilbacher, president of the Bismark Corporation, an advertising and marketing consulting company in Dennis, Mass., had been hired to manage the review. Mr. Vagi declined to discuss the reasons prompting the review.

headline: Chrysler President In Stock Sale
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation's president and chief operating officer, Robert Lutz, sold 30,651 shares of Chrysler stock for about $1.6 million last week, joining other company executives who have sold shares after their recent rise in price.   Mr. Lutz's sale was tied to his exercise of options on about 37,000 shares, the company said. That means he used options to buy the shares at the option price and immediately sold them.

headline: Market Place; Good earnings and a stock buyback please Kodak investors.
abstract: FINALLY, some good news from Rochester. The Eastman Kodak Company, long a disappointing performer, delivered earnings near the high end of expectations yesterday and said it would spend $1 billion to buy back 2.5 percent of its stock in the next six to nine months.   Earnings for the quarter were $338 million, up 33 percent from operating earnings a year earlier. Investors responded positively to the report, sending the price of Kodak's shares on the New York Stock Exchange up $2.50, to $59.625, a gain of nearly 4.4 percent.

headline: Accounts
abstract: L.A. Gear Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., to Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle a print advertising campaign for 1996 aimed at women. TBWA Chiat/Day, Venice, Calif., a unit of the Omnicom Group, resigned the creative portion of the L.A. Gear account last week. The billings were not disclosed. Tristate BMW Advertising Association, Mount Kisco, N.Y., to DeWitt Media, New York, to handle the media portion of its account, previously handled by Ally & Gargano, New York, which is closing. DeWitt was also named to handle media duties for the Philadelphia dealers association. The billings were estimated at $5 million. The media assignment came after DeVito/Verdi, New York, was named to handle the creative portion of the account, also previously at Ally; DeVito/Verdi was also awarded the creative duties for the Philadelphia dealers account.

headline: Retired, And Still Saving
abstract: CHARLES HUSKEY was terrified when he was pushed into retirement five years ago at the age of 54.  Mr. Huskey, a Bedford, Tex., manager at an oil company, had amassed pensions from two companies and two tax-favored retirement accounts, and he had squirreled away several hundred thousand dollars in other savings, but he was still worried. "What if I live to be 105? What's enough?"

headline: Lilco Not a Typical Case In Public Takeover Drives
abstract: If the Long Island Lighting Company ends up being acquired by a New York State agency, overnight it would become the largest publicly owned local electric utility in the country.  The proposed Lilco takeover stands out as a special case in the drive to form public power companies because of its sheer scale and tortured history. Still, it also reflects the desire of politicians to win the public's favor by promising to deliver lower electric power rates to their constituents.

headline: Dow Declines 9.40 Points, Despite Technology Issues' Gains
abstract: Stock prices weakened yesterday, beginning with a round of computer-guided sell orders and ending with anticipation about expected earnings reports from Intel and Microsoft.   Intel, after the stock market closed, said its third-quarter profits rose 38 percent, to $1.05 a share; its shares closed up 3/8, at 63 1/8. Microsoft, which is scheduled to report its results today, advanced 1/2, to 86 3/4.

headline: What Makes Trump Tick?
abstract: To the Editor:   I was appalled that you published Donald Trump's paean to himself, his property and his ego as a column, rather than as a paid ad. It is not news that Mr. Trump is shamelessly in love with himself, but do you share this infatuation? NORMA J. HART  Manhattan, Sept. 17

headline: Neftyanyye Kamni Journal; Caspian Sun on the Rise, Chasing Russian Shadow
abstract: Sabir Guseynov snagged another thumb-size shrimp from the seawater lapping at his feet, then recalled the day 44 years ago when he boarded a boat and, 20 miles from shore, beheld this oil town on the Caspian Sea.   "It was a place of wonder," said Mr. Guseynov, 64, fishing in the oil town on stilts where he has labored since 1951, a 48-mile-long grid of paved bridges, derricks and nine-story apartment blocks housing 2,500 workers. "It was a legend in the open sea."

headline: NEW PLAN REALTY TO PURCHASE 9 SHOPPING CENTERS
abstract: New Plan Realty Trust said yesterday that it would buy nine shopping centers for $126 million, including $88 million in cash, from several sellers. Seven of the centers are in Michigan, including one each in Lansing, Farmington, Saginaw, Flint, Shelby, Rochester Hills and Westland. The others are in Middletown, N.Y., and Elyria, Ohio, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The real estate investment trust, based in New York, said the transaction involved centers that have a combined total of about 1.7 million square feet of retail space. The acquisition will increase the holdings of New Plan to 149 properties in 21 states, the company said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Conill Names 4 Managing Partners
abstract: A month after Carlos R. Rossi, the chairman and chief executive at Conill Advertising in New York, left the agency, changes are being made in top management.         Four senior executives are being promoted to the new positions of managing partners at Conill, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising North America that specializes in advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. The executives are Luz de Armas, 39, senior vice president and creative director, who was also  promoted to the new position of chief creative officer; Paul Melter, 40, the chief financial officer; Nancy Pendas-Smith, 40, vice president and account director, who was also promoted to the new position of president, and Nancy Tellet, 37, senior vice president and media director, who was named to the new position of communications director.

headline: Donaldson in South Africa
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. has formed an investment banking joint venture in South Africa with an affiliate of New Africa Investments Ltd. Donaldson, a unit of the Equitable Companies, will become a major investor in Pleiade Investments, an investment and merchant bank recently begun by New Africa, one of South Africa's largest black-controlled companies. Pleiade, based in Johannesburg, offers traditional investment banking services.

headline: INTERMET SAYS OFFER WAS UNSOLICITED
abstract: The Intermet Corporation, a maker of precision iron parts for auto makers and other industrial customers, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited offer worth $337.5 million from GWM Inc. of Atlanta and Kelso & Company, the New York-based investment bank, to acquire all of Intermet's common stock for $13.50 a share in cash. The stock of Intermet, which has moved its headquarters from Atlanta to Detroit, rose $1.875, to $13.125, on Nasdaq. "It's an absurdly low offer," said Phillip Fricke, a Prudential Securities analyst. Intermet said its board had not yet reviewed the proposal. Intermet reported a loss of $11 million on sales of $501 million in 1994.

headline: Berlin Opposition Set Back
abstract: In another sign of the crisis facing Germany's principal opposition party, voters in Berlin dealt the Social Democratic Party a defeat in mayoral elections today.   Televised projections gave the Social Democrats just 26 percent of the vote, down from the 36 percent they won here in last year's parliamentary election.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Munich Bank Considering Oppenheimer Acquisition
abstract: Bayerische Vereinsbank A.G. said today that it was in talks to buy Oppenheimer & Company, which would give the Munich bank a foothold on Wall Street and end Oppenheimer's search for more capital.         "Bayerische Vereinsbank and Oppenheimer are in talks and examining the possibility of working together," Thomas Pfaff, a spokesman for Bayerische Vereinsbank, said. An Oppenheimer spokesman, John Ryan, also confirmed the talks.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * K'nex Industries, Hatfield, Pa., to Ground Zero, Venice, Calif., to create a holiday-season television advertising campaign for K'nex construction toys. The campaign, with a budget of $8 million to $10 million, includes three commercials. The K'nex account was most recently handled in-house. * Uunet Technologies, Fairfax, Va., to Donino & Partners, Atlanta, to handle advertising for the Internet services company, previously handled in-house. The billings were estimated at $4 million to $8 million.

headline: International Briefs; Merger Plan Depresses German Retailers' Stock
abstract: Shares in the German retail companies Kaufhof Holding A.G. and Asko Deutsche Kaufhaus A.G. fell more than 5 percent yesterday because of concern over the proposed merger with their majority shareholder, the Swiss company, Metro. Terms of the share exchange, which was announced on Monday, will not be fixed until independent auditors value both companies.

headline: International Briefs; Bidders for Power Plants
abstract: National Power P.L.C. said yesterday that it had selected a short list of bidders for three coal-fired power plants generating 4,000 megawatts of electricity. The list so far includes the Eastern Group, a unit of Hanson P.L.C.; the Enron Corporation of Houston, and the AES Corporation of Arlington, Va. National Power said it expected a deal to be made by the end of March. The company, which on Monday agreed to acquire Southern Electric P.L.C. for $:2.8 billion, said the sale would raise around $:1 billion. (Reuters)

headline: Market Place; Zell's Rockefeller deal is delayed and other bids will be considered.
abstract: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES Inc., the real estate investment trust that is scheduled to take ownership of Rockefeller Center, delayed its deal yesterday with an investor group led by the Chicago financier Sam Zell while it considered two other offers made in the last week.   The real estate investment trust, or REIT, said it would not exercise its option to require the Zell group, which includes the General Electric Company, the Walt Disney Company and an investment fund managed by Mr. Zell and Merrill Lynch, to buy a 9.7 percent stake for $10 million.

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about the performance of the Kaufmann Fund referred incorrectly to the Montgomery Small Cap mutual fund, which was recommended as an alternative investment. The Montgomery fund is not open to new investors.

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.25   5.25   4.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.74   4.67        3-MO. headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Mexicans Reach New Pact On Wages and Prices  The Mexican Government signed a new agreement with labor and business intended to control prices, limit salaries and cut public spending, in an attempt to restore stability and economic growth. The pact does not include any controls on exchange rates, an issue of concern to both foreign and domestic investors who have been hurt severely by instability in the peso-dollar exchange rate.  [ Page D2. ] Praxair, a large producer of industrial gases, offered $2.1 billion for CBI Industries, the world's largest producer of carbon dioxide. Praxair, which was spun off from Union Carbide in 1992, said it would pay $32 a share, a 59 percent premium over the $20.125 closing price of CBI shares on Friday. Praxair made public its offer after six months of unsuccessful talks with CBI, which said it would review the offer.  [ D2. ] Budget Conferees Gather  Republican leaders in the House and Senate said they would meet today to start ironing out differences in the budget bills passed last week. President Clinton has said he will veto the bill, and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska said the Republicans should negotiate with Congressional Democrats instead of focusing on Mr. Clinton.  [ A1. ] Leeson to Return to Singapore  Nicholas W. Leeson, the futures trader accused of ruining Barings of London, said he would return to Singapore to face forgery and fraud charges, ending his fight to prevent extradition from Germany, where he was arrested in March.  [ D2. ] Good News for Insurers  The cost of environmental cleanups is not quite the disaster for insurance companies that was once feared, a number of studies have found, in part because claims for restoration of natural resources, like lakes polluted by acid rain, have not materialized.  [ D2. ] Cable Prices Climb  Prices for cable television service have resumed their rise, even as Congress is completing legislation that would unfetter the industry.  [ D7. ] All the Nostalgia, All the Time  Hoping to capitalize on the success of its Nick at Nite cable channel, MTV Networks plans to offer a cable channel early next year that is devoted to nostalgic television shows.  [ D7. ] Sybase Seeks a Turnaround  Sybase is hoping that its latest version of its SQL Server will restore its competitive edge -- and its earnings growth.  [ D4. ] Forget the Aston Martin  BMW of North America and its new advertising agency have developed an aggressive campaign that features Pierce Brosnan, who as James Bond drives a BMW in the latest 007 film. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.  [ D10. ] Turning On the Lights  Experiments are under way to demonstrate that chunks of silicon can be used to run the nation's electrical power network much the way a computer is operated.  [ D5. ] When Systems Crash  The Food and Drug Administration has spent $13 million on a computer system to help it identify tainted food and medicine from abroad, but the General Accounting Office said that the system doesn't work.  [ A13. ]

headline: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES IN MERGER TALKS
abstract: The stock of Mark Twain Bancshares Inc. jumped yesterday after the company said it was in talks about a possible merger. John P. Dubinsky, president and chief executive of the bank holding company based in St. Louis, would not comment further on the talks. Mark Twain has assets of $2.83 billion. The company has been discussed as a possible buyout candidate, particularly since recent changes in Federal banking regulations eliminated protection from out-of-state suitors for Missouri banks. Mark Twain shares jumped $2.875, to $37.875, in Nasdaq trading yesterday; the company's market value exceeded $600 million. Earlier, the shares rose to a 52-week high of $39.

headline: Polaroid Picks An Outsider As New Chief
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation, under pressure to increase its share price and develop new products to spur sales, named the Black & Decker Corporation's No. 2 executive, Gary T. DiCamillo, chairman and chief executive.   Mr. DiCamillo, the first outsider ever to head Polaroid, is a marketer who increased profits and sales during his nine years at Black & Decker.

headline: Cramer-Krasselt's Orlando Purchase
abstract: Cramer-Krasselt has acquired BBC Marketing in Orlando, Fla., for undisclosed terms and merged it with the Cramer-Krasselt office there. Peter Krivkovich, president of Cramer-Krasselt in Chicago, said the combined office in Orlando, with 22 employees, would have billings estimated at more than $14 million from clients like the Florida Department of Citrus. Francesca Matthews, vice president and general manager of Cramer-Krasselt's Orlando office, continues in that role at the combined shop; Joseph Bouch, president and chief exeucutive of BBC, runs the account service department as client services director.

headline: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1996 Saturn SL2; G.M.'s Satellite: A New Spin
abstract: I WILL not soon forget my first test drive of the original Saturn. In November 1989, at General Motors' Arizona test track, a wild boar darted in front of me as I gunned down a straightaway. Unable to avoid him, I clipped his hindquarters. The boar lay whimpering at the side of the road until a security guard put him out of his misery.  The experience was memorable, but not because of the car. And so it is with Saturn buyers and their automobiles.

headline: TBWA Chiat/Day Executive Resigns
abstract: Tony DeGregorio, a well-known creative director who jointly oversees the creative output of the New York office of TBWA Chiat/Day, a unit of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that he would leave that agency "to pursue other interests." Marty Cooke, with whom Mr. DeGregorio has shared his duties since the merger of TBWA and Chiat/Day in August, becomes the sole creative director.   "This is not a personality thing," Mr. DeGregorio said. "This is a personal decision on my part, because this is not the job I came to TBWA for." Mr. DeGregorio, 48, joined what was TBWA Advertising in July 1994 as an executive vice president and the executive creative director.

headline: 2 Media Giants Seen Forming A Rival to ESPN
abstract: In an effort to become major competitors to ESPN, Tele-Communications Inc. and the News Corporation are negotiating the formation of a new global sports network, two people with knowledge of the discussions said yesterday.   The cable service, which could be announced as early as this week, would be run by the News Corporation and Liberty Media, the programming arm of Tele-Communications. Liberty owns a number of regional sports cable services that could provide programming for the service. The News Corporation, led by Rupert Murdoch, has been aggressively acquiring sports rights in the United States and overseas.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: XILINX INC., San Jose, Calif., will invest $150 million for a 25 percent stake in a new-venture company formed with United Microelectronics Corp., a chip maker based in Taiwan, and several other companies. The venture company will build a semiconductor plant in Hsin Chu City, Taiwan.  AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP., Madison, N.J., a drug company, made a $15 million investment in Medimmune Inc. by aquiring 967,742 shares at $15.50 each. ASHLAND COAL INC., Huntington, W.Va., a coal mining and processing company, planned to repurchase up to one million of its common shares. Ashland currently has about 13 million common shares outstanding. MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Washington, said it would open a new sales and service center in Newport News, Va., eventually bringing 1,300 jobs to the community.
