headline: People
abstract: Eugene P. Beard, chief financial officer of the Interpublic Group of Cos., New York, was named to the additional new position of vice chairman for finance and operations. Jeff DeJoseph, executive vice president and director for account planning and strategic services at Bates USA, New York, has resigned to join the New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Co., a unit of the WPP Group, in the new post of executive vice president and account planning director. At Bates, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., Sarah Hatch was named to assume Mr. DeJoseph's responsibilities on an interim basis, in the new post of senior vice president and account planning director. She previously held a similar post at Gold Greenlees Trott, London.

headline: Midas Switches To Thompson
abstract: Two consumer product marketers are changing agencies.   The Midas International Corporation named the Chicago office of the J. Walter Thompson Company to handle its national advertising account, with billings estimated at $23 million. The Chicago office of Wells Rich Greene BDDP had handled the account for the last 25 years until resigning in July when Midas began a review.

headline: JAMESWAY CONSIDERS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: The Jamesway Corporation, which emerged from bankruptcy in December, said yesterday that it was considering filing for bankruptcy protection again. The company, a discount retailer based in Secaucus, N.J., said it might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because of weak sales, poor results and constricted trade credit. The company made the announcement after the stock market closed. Earlier on the New York Stock Exchange, its shares fell 25 cents, to $1, their lowest price since the company emerged from Chapter 11. The company, which has lost money in 16 of the last 20 quarters, filed for bankruptcy in July 1994, emerging in December with a $115 million line of credit.

headline: STRUCTURAL CHANGE FOR PACIFIC GAS AND ELECTRIC
abstract: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said yesterday that it planned to transfer its assets to a holding company, creating a more flexible corporate structure. The San Francisco-based power company, the nation's largest publicly held utility, said its shareholders would receive stock in the newly created company. P.G.& E. would be a subsidiary of the holding company, which is expected to be set up by mid-1996. Two existing subsidiaries, the Pacific Gas Transmission Company and PG&E Enterprises, would also be transferred to the holding company.

headline: Simplifying the Tax Code Isn't So Simple
abstract: Proposals to overhaul the Federal income tax system share two stated goals: to make the tax code simpler and fairer. But the debate in Washington, and among taxpayers across the country, shows the complexities of making such changes. Peter Passell's look at the proposals ("The Tax Code Heads Into the Operating Room," Sept. 3) drew many reader reactions, including various responses to its discussion of plans for a so-called flat tax. To the Editor:   No one is watching the debate about tax reform with greater interest than those of us at the Internal Revenue Service, and no one is more dedicated to making our tax system, whatever it may be, more efficient.

headline: MALLINCKRODT SELLS ANIMAL FEED UNIT FOR $110 MILLION
abstract: Mallinckrodt Group Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its animal feed ingredients business to the IMC-Agrico Company for $110 million. Mallinckrodt, a maker of health products and specialty chemicals that is based in St. Louis, said that the feed ingredients unit was profitable but that its growth prospects were not in line with the rest of the company. The unit had sales of $169 million in its latest fiscal year, while Mallinckrodt had sales of $2.2 billion during the period, which ended June 30. IMC-Agrico is a joint venture between IMC Global Inc. of Northbrook, Ill., and Freeport-McMoRan Resource Partners L.P., which is part of Freeport-McMoRan Inc. of New Orleans.

headline: British Pension Trustees Sue Morgan Stanley
abstract: The trustees of a Mirror Group P.L.C. pension fund have sued a subsidiary of the Morgan Stanley Group, charging that it lost $100 million in securities held on behalf of the fund shortly before the mysterious death in 1991 of the company's owner, Robert Maxwell.   The lawsuit against the Morgan Stanley Trust Company, filed late on Friday in United States District Court in Manhattan, seeks to recover the full value of the securities plus interest and punitive damages.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Family Member in New Bid For Rockefeller Center  An investor group made up of David Rockefeller, Tishman-Speyer Properties Inc. and the Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P. has offered to pay $296.5 million, or $7.75 a share, for all the shares of Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that is poised to take ownership of Rockefeller Center.   The investor group would also assume about $800 million of the real estate investment trust's debt, about $191 million of which is owed to Whitehall, a real estate investment fund managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, and a Goldman, Sachs subsidiary.  [ Page D2. ]   Clinton to Ease Computer Sales  President Clinton is preparing to relax restrictions on the export of high-performance computers, handing technology companies a long-sought victory.  [ A1. ]   NBC Stretches Its On-Line Reach  Software that NBC is expected to introduce today will allow audio and video feeds to be received simultaneously through the World Wide Web at transmission speeds now attainable by most home computers.  [ D9. ] Making an Impact on Imprints  In a sign of how Hollywood has penetrated the world of books, several film producers are becoming book publishers themselves, hoping to lure writers with lucrative deals that most old-line houses cannot match. Mary B. W. Tabor: Publishing.  [ D9. ] New Support for European Currency  European Union finance ministers and central bankers reaffirmed a commitment to create a single European currency by 1999.  [ D6. ] The Lure of Software Careers  A generation of college graduates with no technical training is streaming into the software business.  [ A1. ] Return of Regular Programming  Now that the O. J. Simpson case has gone to the jury, the broadcasters that carried virtually every minute of the trial plan to go back to doing what they do best.  [ D9. ] Untangling the Web's Data Bases  Few would call the Internet's World Wide Web well-organized, but for Architext Software, the Web's complexity has created an opportunity. Architext hopes to popularize its method for finding information on the Web.  [ D5. ] Video-Game Hotshot No More  In consumer electronics, the 3DO Company found, being first guarantees nothing. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce.  [ D5. ] An On-Line Discount Club  The newest entrant in the Internet shopping derby has a data base of more than 250,000 discount-price products and a history that dates to the 1970's.  [ D5. ]   Third-Quarter Winners and Losers  The best performers on the major exchanges in the third quarter featured, no surprise, technology issues.  [ D6. ] A New Breed of Mascot  In the tradition of so many magazines, Conde Nast Publications is adopting its own mascot. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.  [ D10. ]

headline: Western Nuclear Powers To Sign Pacific Accord
abstract: The United States, Britain and France have announced that they will sign the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty in a move to help reduce tensions between the region and the Western nuclear powers.   France said, however, that it will continue its present series of nuclear tests in the South Pacific, begun in September, before joining the treaty.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MENTOR GRAPHICS CORP., Wilsonville, Ore., a provider of electronic design automation systems, acquired Precedence Inc. Santa Clara, Calif., a software maker, for stock. The amount was not disclosed.  MONRO MUFFLER / BRAKE INC., Rochester, signed a letter of intent with the Quaker State Corp., Oil City, Pa., to build 10 to 20 oil-change shops bearing the Q Lube name. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: A Joint Venture For Guerlain
abstract: Guerlain S.A., the French fragrance and cosmetics company that markets brands like Shalimar, has selected as the lead agency on the creative portion of its worldwide account an unusual joint venture between shops based in New York and Paris. The billings are not being disclosed but could reach as much as $100 million by 1997.   The joint venture was formed in August, a month after Guerlain began a review on the account, by two agencies already on the Guerlain roster: Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano in New York and Australie in Paris, a unit of Euro RSCG. The joint venture was a finalist in the review along with another Guerlain roster shop, the Paris office of TBWA International, owned by the Omnicom Group.

headline: The U.N. at 50: An On-Line History
abstract: Articles and photos from the archives of The New York Times on the birth of the United Nations in 1945 are available on @times, the Times service on America Online. Software and information: (800) 548-5201.

headline: Fisons Tells Holders to Take Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Bid
abstract: Fisons P.L.C. surrendered yesterday to a hostile takeover bid by Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the big French-American drug company. Fisons advised its shareholders to accept Rhone-Poulenc Rorer's latest offer of $2.89 billion.    Rhone-Poulenc Rorer said the deal would strengthen its position in the highly profitable global market for asthma and allergy treatments, which has sales of $9 billion a year.

headline: UAL EXPECTS EARNINGS TO EXCEED EXPECTATIONS
abstract: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that it expected third-quarter earnings to exceed Wall Street predictions. The Chicago-based air carrier attributed its outlook to higher domestic fares, strong traffic and efforts to control expenses. In the third quarter of last year, UAL earned $6.86 a share. A First Call Inc. consensus of 12 analysts' estimates forecasts a profit of $8.39 a share. UAL's stock rose $1.875 a share yesterday, to $168.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Cellular-Phone Account in Review
abstract: Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile, the cellular-phone venture of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation, said yesterday that it had placed its account in review. Billings for the account, which has been split among four agencies, were estimated at $50 million.   "We are interested in consolidating for effectiveness," Jim Gerace, a spokesman for Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobil in Bedminster, N.J., said in confirming a report of the review this week in Adweek. The company is considering the four shops now handling the account, he added, along with other undisclosed agencies. A decision is expected by the end of the month, Mr. Gerace said.

headline: HEALTHSOUTH AGREES TO ACQUIRE CAREMARK UNIT
abstract: The Healthsouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the orthopedic rehabilitation business of Caremark International Inc. for $127.5 million. Healthsouth said Caremark Orthopedic Services Inc., has more than 120 outpatient centers in 13 states. The company expects revenues of nearly $80 million this year. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., had revenues of $1.1 billion last year and currently operates nearly 600 outpatient and rehabilitation centers. Caremark is based in Northbrook, Ill.

headline: Safety Fears Fail to Deter Armenians On A-Plant
abstract: This energy-starved nation, where most homes have electricity just hours a day, plans to restart a nuclear reactor here this week despite Western protests that it is unsafe.  Armenian officials say the plant meets international standards, and they reject United States claims that the reactor, which was closed in 1989 because of safety concerns, is unfit to withstand the area's serious earthquakes.

headline: Dispute Over Tapes Further Sours U.S.-Colombia Relations
abstract: In a new blow to relations between Colombia and the United States, the Clinton Administration has reacted angrily to a public airing in Colombia this week of recordings that are said to be wiretapped conversations of the top American drug enforcement officials there.   Carlos Alonso Lucio, a former leftist guerrilla who is a member of the Colombian Parliament, played the tapes in Parliament on Wednesday, saying they showed that American drug officials were conspiring against Colombia's Government.

headline: International Briefs; Compagnie de Suez Loss
abstract: Compagnie de Suez said early today that it lost $800 million in the first half of the year as a result of a charge involving its exposure to the depressed French property market. Suez, one of the pillars of the French financial establishment, reported a loss of 3.98 billion francs, in contrast to a profit of 795 million francs, or $353 million, in the period a year earlier. The results included a one-time charge of $820 million on its property business. Suez took a similar $353 million charge in the first half of 1994. (Reuters)

headline: Softkey, in Separate Deals, Seeks 2 Educational Software Makers
abstract: Softkey International Inc. began a hostile takeover bid valued at $606 million yesterday for the Learning Company, which had previously agreed to be acquired by Broderbund Inc.   Softkey also announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the Minnesota Educational Computing Corporation of Minneapolis in a stock swap valued at $370 million.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; Inspire Them to Own The Funds They Tout
abstract: IS your butcher a vegetarian? Your doctor a Christian Scientist? Have you spotted your Chevy dealer driving a Honda?  Probably not. But if you're a mutual fund investor, you may have handed your money to a manager who won't put his own cash into the fund he's pushing for you. And you have no way to find out if that's the case.

headline: Acquisition by Conmed
abstract: The Conmed Corporation, based in Utica, agreed this week to acquire substantially all of the business and assets of New Dimensions in Medicine Inc., except for its international wound-care business, for about $32 million in cash. New Dimensions said it had terminated its previously reported discussions with Tyco International Inc. because it believed the Conmed transaction would result in significantly higher value to its shareholders. New Dimensions expects to distribute about $5 a share to its shareholders from the Conmed transaction and the sale of its international wound-care business to another buyer.

headline: HEINZ ANNOUNCES TEMPORARY PRODUCTION CUTS
abstract: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it would curtail production temporarily at five United States food-processing plants and furlough some workers under a plan to pare costs and reduce inventories. About 400 of the 700 hourly workers at its Pittsburgh plant would be idled for 10 weeks over six months, starting at the end of November, said Deb Magness, a spokeswoman for Heinz. There would be sporadic shutdowns in production of baby food and soup at the plant through April. Ms. Magness said temporary production shutdowns were also planned at four seasonal plants: a ketchup plant in Tracey, Calif.; a gravy and ketchup factory in Muscatine, Iowa; a pickle plant in Holland, Mich., and a condiments and ketchup plant in Fremont, Ohio.

headline: Ex-East German Spymaster Finds Polishing His Image Is Hard
abstract: No eggs or rotten tomatoes were thrown at Markus Wolf when he delivered a lecture in Berlin recently, as some had feared, but many spectators were nonetheless unhappy with the former East German spymaster's efforts to rehabilitate himself.         Mr. Wolf confessed to no crimes or sins or even misjudgments. Serving for nearly four decades as deputy director of the hated secret police known as the Stasi, he asserted, was "a great honor, a duty, a chance to do something for our country."

headline: Agency Is Renamed As HMS Partners
abstract: Hameroff/Milenthal/Spence in Columbus, Ohio, has been revamped and renamed after completing the acquisition of Chuck Ruhr Advertising in Minneapolis.   Hameroff/Milenthal/Spence, which has more than 280 employees, has become HMS Partners Ltd., with offices in Atlanta, Cincinnati, Memphis and Miami as well as Columbus and Minneapolis. Billings from clients like Carnival Cruise Lines and the Procter & Gamble Company are estimated at $180 million.

headline: Charge Taken By Donaldson
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. has taken a $25 million pretax charge in the third quarter related to a short-term loan to a client, people close to the company said yesterday.   The firm, a unit of the Equitable Companies, made the loan to the Coram Healthcare Corporation, a Denver company that provides services in patients' homes, the people close to the company said.

headline: Dean Witter Alters Broker Commissions
abstract: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said yesterday that it would stop paying higher commissions to its brokers for selling its own financial products. It was the last of the major brokerage firms to make such a change.   The leading securities firms stopped offering enhanced commissions for sales of proprietary products after a Securities and Exchange Commission panel criticized the practice in April.

headline: OLYMPIA'S U.S. UNIT FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
abstract: Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.), the American subsidiary of Olympia & York Development Ltd., filed yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors as part of its proposed restructuring of $5 billion worth of debt. Yesterday's filing at Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan follows approval by the company's board on Sept. 21 of a restructuring plan that may give control of the company to a group of creditors led by the Bronfman family of Toronto. The plan, which will be presented at a bankruptcy court hearing scheduled for Oct. 26, is opposed by a group of creditors seeking control of the reorganized company, led by the Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund and Tishman Speyer Properties Inc.

headline: DISPLEASURE AMONG ARCHER-DANIELS SHAREHOLDERS
abstract: Some large Archer-Daniels-Midland Company shareholders will vote against directors at next week's annual meeting, saying the board has not responded appropriately to a widening federal criminal investigation. New Jersey already sent in a proxy voting its 6 million shares against re-electing the 17 directors at the Oct. 19 meeting because "they haven't done their duty," said Roland Machold, director ofthe state's division of investment. The New York City Comptroller, Alan Hevesi, recommended yesterday that the city's funds, which hold 2.8 million shares, do the same. A final vote on that will come Monday.

headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS; Heirs With Hairy Faces . . . and Wet Noses, Too
abstract: Q. I'm interested in leaving money to make sure that my two dogs and cats are well cared for after I'm gone. What's the best way to accomplish this? A few people have found this to be a silly idea, but I'm serious. KATHY LEFAUVE Snyder, N.Y. A. Upon his death in 1880, Jonathan Jackson of Ohio left directions that his money be used to build a kind of Yale Club for cats -- a posh residence and drop-in center where strays could grab a meal, crash for the night, gossip with their cronies or listen to accordion concerts in a small auditorium. "It is man's duty, as lord of animals, to watch over and protect the lesser and feebler," he wrote.  You can bet Mr. Jackson's biped survivors were not amused by his quirky bequest. But if you own a dog or cat -- or any other type of pet, from a Rottweiler to a pygmy vole -- there is nothing silly about making formal arrangements for its care should you die first. "You wouldn't think of going on vacation without arranging for your animals to be fed and cared for," says Reynaldo Samala, executive director of the New York office of Bide-a-Wee Home Association. "Shouldn't you make similar preparations for when you're gone permanently?"  At the very least, this means providing the animal with a home, a competent and caring owner, basic amenities like food and medical care, and a life style similar to what it now has. "All these arrangements can be written into your will," says John O. McManus, a New York lawyer specializing in estate planning. If you're so disposed, he adds, you may want to consider burial arrangements.  Most pet owners never get around to making such provisions, largely for the same reason they neglect to write wills in the first place -- "because they don't really expect to die," says Mary Lehman, a Bankers Trust managing director and former head of its trusts and estate department. Not surprisingly, those who do write their pets into their wills tend to be elderly owners, for whom a dog or cat may be a sole companion.  Regardless of one's age, it's prudent to make final arrangements. After all, we're all mortal, and an unforeseen accident -- is there another kind? -- can suddenly remove a young pet owner from the picture. (Certain species come with an all-but-ironclad guarantee of outliving their owners. A couple I know in their 40's own a Chilean land tortoise that they fully expect to usher in the 22d century.)  The first step is to choose a new owner -- ideally a trusted friend or relative who knows the animal and its idiosyncrasies and is willing and able to accommodate them. An 85-pound Irish Setter that spends its days romping outdoors clearly won't adjust well to life in a studio apartment; a shedding angora cat isn't an ideal companion for a neat freak.  Mismatches can be stressful to both animals and humans, and if things get really hairy, the new owner may wind up giving the animal to someone you would find unacceptable. Of course, it's a good idea to consult with the person you wish to designate as owner and caretaker. "Imagine someone phoning you to say, 'Congratulations -- your Aunt Sally has died and left you her 12-year-old crippled Great Dane to care for,' " says Ms. Lehman. "Sounds crazy, but it happens more than you'd think."  Because the cost of pet food, veterinary care and other necessaries can add up, you may want to earmark some money for those purposes. The easiest way -- if not necessarily the smartest -- is to bequeath the funds to the new owner. The problem is that there is no legal mechanism to guarantee that the money won't be spent on golf clubs or aluminum siding instead of kibble.  To discourage financial abuses, you can have a lawyer set up a trust, administered by a bank that dispenses the funds and that certifies their intended use. While a trust adds a layer of protection, "it makes sense only when there is a substantial bequest, since it involves considerable legal and accounting fees and yearly tax returns," Ms. Lehman says. "It wouldn't make sense to set up a trust for $5,000."  Trusts are not absolutely tamper proof, either. In their book, "Beyond the Grave" (Harper Business, 1995, $23), the lawyers Gerald M. and Jeffrey L. Condon tell of an elderly client named Mrs. Green who left instructions that her black Labrador, Chauncy, continue to live at home after her death. In exchange for free rent and a monthly stipend of $1,000 from the "Chauncy Trust," a neighbor named Mr. McSorley moved into the house and saw to the pooch's needs. The deal was to last as long as Chauncy lived.  Twice a year, a bank trust officer checked on Mr. McSorley to verify all was well. The officer eventually left the bank, and a successor took over his duties. Later, the successor too was replaced. During 12 years, "six different trust officers were assigned to the Chauncy Trust," the authors write, "all of them paying Mr. McSorley's salary, and all of them checking up on Chauncy's health."   Chauncy was nine when Mrs. Green died, meaning he would have reached the hoary age of 21 in Mr. McSorley's care. In fact, he died at 14. Mr. McSorley promptly replaced him with a look-alike black Lab, also named Chauncy. When Chauncy 2d died, Mr. McSorley simply bought another. "Whenever a new trust officer dropped by," the Condons write, "Chauncy was there, and Mr. McSorley still got his salary -- and a free place to live."  If you can't think of anyone to entrust with your pet, many charities and shelters will take dogs and cats and place them in good homes in exchange for a donation or a bequest. Before you sign anything, make sure you visit their premises and understand exactly how they operate. "You do not want a charity that will dump your pet on the first willing person it finds," say the Condons. Nor do you want your pet to live out its remaining years in a wire cage.  As a rule, leaving money directly to a pet in your will is not wise. It makes for a will that can be easily challenged and broken.  Not every will is reduced to tatters by furious heirs, though. One of my favorites in the annals of pet lore is the tale of Tommie, a 28-pound house cat who inherited $200,000, an opulent home and the services of a full-time housekeeper upon the death of his mistress, Mrs. Andree P. Monst of North Carolina, in 1965. No need to fear, sudden wealth didn't change Tommie, described as a mean cat long before its inheritance came through. "I tried to pet it, and it bit me," a neighbor said of Tommie. "I was just trying to be friendly."   Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or they can be sent by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

headline: CNN and Dow Jones Business News Services to Square Off on AT&T On-Line Forum
abstract: Next week, when business professionals subscribing to AT&T's Interchange on-line service turn to their computers for up-to-date information, they will have two familiar choices in financial news providers. In one corner of the screen will be the logo for CNN Interactive, the new digital version of the Cable News Network. In the other corner will be one for the Dow Jones Business Center, from the publisher of Barron's and The Wall Street Journal.   CNN Interactive said last week that it had reached a long-term agreement to deliver multimedia business news on the AT&T Business Network, which is scheduled to begin Oct. 30 as part of the AT&T Interchange Online Network, a new competitor to services like Compuserve and America Online.

headline: A DAY LATER, MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES SAYS TALKS ARE OFF
abstract: Mark Twain Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had terminated negotiations for a possible merger. Only a day earlier, the company announced that it was in talks with a party it did not identify. Mark Twain Bancshares, based in St. Louis, said the two sides had not been able to agree on the terms of a merger. The company, a bank holding company with about $2.83 billion in assets, said it "cannot predict whether or when these discussions may resume." News of the merger talks pushed Mark Twain's stock to a 52-week high on Monday. Yesterday, the stock dropped $2.375, to close at $35.50 in Nasdaq trading.

headline: International Briefs; Statoil Bids for Aran And ARCO Withdraws
abstract: Statoil, the Norwegian oil company, bid 198 million Irish pounds ($318 million) yesterday for Aran Energy P.L.C. of Ireland, knocking a rival suitor, ARCO, out of the picture. ARCO, based in Los Angeles, had previously made a hostile bid of 178 million Irish pounds for Aran.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bavarian Law Orders Crucifixes for Schools
abstract: The Bavarian state parliament today passed a new law ordering crucifixes to be hung in school classrooms after the German supreme court ruled the southern state's previous law unconstitutional.         The Federal Constitutional Court ruled in August that Bavaria could not insist that crucifixes hang in state classrooms because this violated the religious freedom enshrined in the constitution.

headline: P.& G. Sales Goal Is $50 Billion by 2000
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that it was confident the company would meet its goal of $50 billion in annual sales by the end of the decade.   John E. Pepper, chairman and chief executive, said the increase in sales, which reached $33.4 billion last year, would be buttressed by strong opportunities in new and developing markets.

headline: Is Kenya Sliding Back Toward Repression?
abstract: If he is found guilty on Monday, a former member of Kenya's Parliament will be sentenced to death by hanging.    Officially, the former official, Koigi wa Wamwere, is charged with attempted robbery with violence, an offense that carries a mandatory death sentence here. The police contend that he raided a police station for weapons, presumably to use for an insurrection.

headline: Levi Strauss Buys Custom-Fit Software Concern
abstract: Signaling its commitment to the notion that finding perfectly fitting jeans should not be a lost cause, Levi Strauss & Company has acquired the Custom Clothing Technology Corporation, the software company that created the technology for custom-fit blue jeans for women.    The companies declined to provide financial terms of the multimillion- dollar deal.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  Nationsbank Corp., Charlotte, N.C, is selling $450 million of subordinated notes due in 2025 through Nationsbank Capital Markets Inc. The notes are priced at 98.531 to yield 7.372 percent. The noncallable issue is rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service, A- by Standard & Poor's Corp. and A by Duff & Phelps.

headline: Advisers Are Mostly Sticking With Stocks
abstract: STAYING in this year's stock market can seem downright greedy.   After all, fund investors are sitting on some of the most impressive gains ever. Stock funds rose 27 percent, on average, while technology funds turned in nearly double that gain in the first nine months.

headline: Lotus Loses More Executives Following Chief's Resignation
abstract: The fallout at I.B.M.'s Lotus Development software unit continues in the wake of the recent resignation by Lotus's chief executive, Jim P. Manzi.   Yesterday, Lotus said that John Landry, the 47-year old chief technology officer at Lotus, had agreed to stay on, but in a part-time consulting role in which he will help develop the International Business Machines Corporation's Internet strategy. No replacement for Mr. Landry as chief technology officer was announced.

headline: ORBIT SEMICONDUCTOR SHARES TUMBLE BY 41%
abstract: The shares of Orbit Semiconductor Inc. fell 41 percent yesterday, a day after the company said third-quarter earnings would probably be about half that expected by analysts. Orbit's shares fell $6.50, to $9, in Nasdaq trading of 1.2 million shares. Orbit, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said after the market closed on Thursday that its third-quarter earnings would probably be 10 cents or 12 cents a share, below the average of 26 cents estimated by three analysts for Zacks Investment Research. The company said its third-quarter revenue would probably be about $13.5 million. Analysts had expected revenue of about $17 million. Orbit makes chips for converting electrical signals, like recorded audio or phone calls, into digital data.

headline: Industrial Output Down In September
abstract: Industrial output declined for the first time in five months during September as cool weather curbed electricity consumption, the Federal Reserve reported today.   Production decreased two-tenths of 1 percent. Output at factories alone increased two-tenths of 1 percent, but that was not enough to offset a 5.4 percent drop in utility output.

headline: DIRECTORS APPROVE THE REPURCHASE OF COMMON STOCK
abstract: The directors of Reebok International Ltd. have approved an additional repurchase of up to $200 million in common stock. The repurchase, approved on Thursday, will be conducted in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions, Reebok, the Stoughton, Mass.-based maker of athletic shoes, said yesterday. The company said it had repurchased 41.1 million shares, for $939.3 million, since its repurchase program started in 1991. With the new authorization, there now is a total of about $257 million approved for share purchases.

headline: International Briefs; Aran Shares Surge
abstract: The shares of Aran Energy P.L.C. surged yesterday after the Dublin-based oil concern said it had received an approach from a company that might top ARCO's hostile bid of $:161 million ($254 million). Shares in Aran rose to 73 pence, a gain of 6, on the London Stock Exchange. More than 6.1 million shares were traded. Aran vigorously opposes ARCO's bid.

headline: International Briefs; Aegon in Mexico Deal
abstract: The Mexican financial group Banamex-Accival said yesterday that it had formed a strategic alliance with the Dutch insurer Aegon to provide insurance services in Mexico. The group said Aegon would acquire a 49 percent stake in its insurance unit, Seguros Banamex. Aegon would pay an initial $167 million, of which $109 million has already been paid, with the rest to be paid over 10 years, depending on the value of the business. Banamex-Accival said a preliminary accord setting up the alliance was announced last November but the Mexican economic crisis had delayed the deal. (Reuters)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Selloff in Technology Issues Pulls Stock Market Down  Technology stocks were battered, leading the stock market to its third straight loss, as Wall Street continued to brace for possible disappointments in third-quarter earnings. The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, dropped 18.18 points, to 1,002.27. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 9.03 points, to 4,740.67.   Technology stocks dropped after an analyst at Soundview Financial Group downgraded five semiconductor makers for the first time in three years, citing rising supplies of computer chips.  [ Page D12. ] Leading Indicators Up 0.2%  The index of leading economic indicators increased for only the second time this year, rising two-tenths of 1 percent in August, indicating moderate expansion in the months ahead. In a separate Government report, factory orders rose 2.6 percent in August on strong demand for cars and trucks.  [ D4. ] The reports helped Treasury prices extend their rally through a fourth consecutive session as expectations continued for another cut in interest rates.  [ D19. ] The dollar fell against most leading currencies as traders took profits. The dollar fell to 100.94 Japanese yen from 101.42 yen and to 1.4349 German marks from 1.4385 marks.  [ D10. ] Ford Sales Fell 9% in September  Following soft September sales reports from its rivals, Ford said its overall vehicle sales for the month fell 9 percent, more than what analysts had expected. The decline was Ford's first monthly sales drop this year.  [ D2. ] Court Orders Extradition of Leeson  A German court ordered that Nicholas W. Leeson, the trader whose $1.35 billion in losses brought down Barings P.L.C., be extradited to Singapore to face 11 charges of fraud, forgery and breach of trust.  [ D6. ] South American Beef Gaining Favor  After decades of being shut out of the world's largest meat markets because of an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease, Argentina and Uruguay have contained the disease among their cattle and are expected to begin shipping fresh and frozen beef to the United States and other countries in the next six months.  [ D6. ] New Club Shakes Up Golf Stocks  The willingness of many golfers to pay $300 for the newest innovation in equipment, a long-shot driver called the Burner Bubble, is unexpectedly putting pressure on the stocks of the industry leaders, the Callaway Golf Company and Cobra Golf. But analysts are unsure how to play this fight for dominance of the $1.5 billion premium club market. Market Place.  [ D12. ] Peddling the New AT&T  Richard A. McGinn, the chief executive of AT&T's giant equipment-manufacturing division, met with senior executives from nine telephone companies at the Telecom '95 trade show in Geneva this week to promote his soon-to-be-independent company and found unanimous support for AT&T's breakup.  [ D4. ] Tough Sell for Simpson TV Special  A number of the larger companies that stage pay-per-view television events have been approached about offering a pay-per-view interview with O. J. Simpson, but the companies have reservations about such an event. "It may have some attraction to people who were voyeurs to this circus, but my reaction is that it would be in extremely bad taste," one executive said.  [ B18. ] Putting Whimsy in the Air  Two new airlines are taking their promotional cue from Southwest Airlines, which has had its flight attendants singing to the tune of the Flintstones and other familiar melodies since its inception in 1971. Valujet has adopted a cartoon of a smiling Boeing 747 as its logo, and Western Pacific has four planes painted with TV's "Simpsons." Advertising.  [ D8. ]

headline: A Unit of G.M. Goes With Bates
abstract: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, has named Bates Worldwide in New York as its worldwide agency of record. The billings were estimated at $40 million.   Bates, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was selected on Friday after a seven-month review that began when E.D.S. decided to seek a single agency to handle its advertising worldwide as part of what the company called a global branding project. A small New York agency, Goldsmith/ Jeffrey, has handled the account in the United States since May 1993.

headline: Rhodes Adds to Stores
abstract: Rhodes Inc., the furniture retailer, has agreed to buy 21 stores and two distribution centers from Weberg Enterprises Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Emmerling Post's Health Care Group
abstract: Emmerling Post Inc. in New York has formed a health care group, Emmerling Post Health/Tec, after the two top executives of Proclinica Inc., a health care agency in New York, joined Emmerling Post and brought their accounts with them.

headline: China Growth Falls to Less Than 10%
abstract: China's economic growth slowed during 1995's first nine months and losses at the nation's companies widened, the State Statistics Bureau said today, but the Government was not expected to ease its tight grip on credit.   Gross domestic product -- the value of the nation's output of goods and services, excluding income from abroad -- grew 9.8 percent in the nine months from the corresponding period a year ago. That was the first time the growth rate has fallen below 10 percent since 1991.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Comcast Corp., Philadelphia, is selling $250 million of senior subordinated debentures due in 2006 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The debentures are priced at 98.99, to yield 9.273 percent. The issue is rated B1 by Moody's Investors Service, B+ by Standard & Poor's and B+ by Duff & Phelps. * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $100 million of bonds due in 1997 through First Tennessee Bank. The bonds, which are callable quarterly beginning Jan. 18, 1996, carry an interest rate of 6 percent and are priced at par. * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., known as Freddie Mac, is selling $45 million of debentures due in 1998 through Suntrust Capital Markets. The debentures are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.26 percent and are priced at par. * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $200 million of medium-term notes due in 1997 through Morgan Stanley & Co. The notes are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6 percent and are priced at par. * SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Brentford, England, is selling $100 million of Yankee notes due in 2005 through CS First Boston Corp. The notes carry an interest rate of 6.625 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's and A+ and S.& P. * Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is selling $45 million of medium-term notes due in 1999 through CS First Boston Corp. The notes, which are callable in two years, carry an interest rate of 6.285 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Japanese Sect Tried to Buy U.S. Arms Technology, Senator Says
abstract: A Japanese sect accused of releasing lethal nerve gas in a Tokyo subway made extensive efforts in the United States, Russia and Australia to buy materials for nuclear and chemical weapons, including laser technology that the United States refuses to sell to suspected terrorist countries, Senator Sam Nunn said today.  Senator Nunn said Congressional investigators had found that the Japanese sect, Aum Shinrikyo, had bought American computer software and air filtering systems that could be used to make chemical and biological weapons, and recruited at least two Russian nuclear scientists.

headline: SYMS ENDING PLANS TO REPURCHASE ITS STOCK
abstract: The Syms Corporation said late yesterday that it was abandoning plans to buy back the company's stock. The company had previously announced that stockholders holding a majority of the shares proposed to buy the shares at $8.75 each. The stock of the company, an off-price apparel retail chain based in Secaucus, N.J., closed unchanged yesterday at $9.

headline: Taking In the Sites;A Christmas Trip Through Cyberspace
abstract: For decades, children scribbled letters to Santa Claus. Now they send E-mail.         "I have been behaving really well this year," Amelia wrote in an electronic message to Santa. "I have no certain presents in mind, though. Except for maybe  my own computer."

headline: Macedonian President Gravely Wounded in Car-Bomb Attack
abstract: The Macedonian President, Kiro Gligorov, a close ally of the United States, was gravely wounded today in a car-bomb attack that killed his driver, senior western diplomats in Skopje said.         The diplomats said Mr. Gligorov, who was struck in the head by three pieces of shrapnel, was suffering from a fractured skull and heavy internal bleeding. Their reports contradicted Macedonian radio, which quoted doctors at the main hospital in Skopje, the capital, as saying that Mr. Gligorov had not been seriously injured in the blast.

headline: JUDGE DENIES REQUEST TO BLOCK A BID FOR BALLY GAMING
abstract: A Federal judge has denied a request by Bally Gaming International Inc. and WMS Industries for a preliminary injunction to block the Alliance Gaming Corporation's hostile effort to acquire Bally. In a Sept. 5 suit, Bally Gaming and WMS argued that Alliance had not adequately disclosed details about its investors and its ability to complete the transaction. United States District Judge Sue Robinson in Wilmington, Del., ruled that enough public information was available on Alliance for investors to make decisions on whether to support Alliance's bid or Bally Gaming's agreement to be acquired by WMS. Alliance said yesterday that it had extended its tender offer to acquire Bally Gaming, which makes slot and video gaming machines and is based in Las Vegas, Nev., to Oct. 16. Alliance has offered to buy 59.5 percent of Bally Gaming's shares for $13 each in cash.

headline: Chase Official to Quit
abstract: Kathylynn O'Donnell will resign as executive vice president and co-head of global markets at the Chase Manhattan Corporation after the bank's $11 billion merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation, she said in an internal memo. Speculation that Ms. O'Donnell would leave Chase emerged the day the merger was announced, when Chemical officials received most of the top positions in the new bank. Ms. O'Donnell joined Chase in 1979.

headline: Taking In the Sites; A World Wide Web of Jazz
abstract: Remember the early days when malls were built but had comparatively few retail outlets, aside from the big department stores that anchored them? The department store went up first. Then other merchants had to decide whether to move into the mall or keep the old storefront that had been on Main Street for three generations.   The business of jazz on the World Wide Web is at just such a juncture -- except that Main Street and the malls are being developed simultaneously. Most of the jazz presence on the Web consists of interlinked sites run by individual labels, festival promoters, management companies and college radio stations.

headline: Mobile Phone Retail Plans
abstract: Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile said it would open nine mobile communications retail stores in New York City next year, creating 150 jobs.   It said it would also invest $200 million to upgrade and expand the region's cellular network next year.

headline: Presentations by Kmart Chief Draw Only Mixed Reviews
abstract: Floyd Hall, the chief executive of the Kmart Corporation, met separately with analysts and investors yesterday to dispel rumors that the discount retailer faces a credit crunch and to describe a plan for improving sagging profits.    That plan includes redesigning most stores and selling certain operations. But like parents demanding to know just where their teen-ager took the car last night, the New York audiences treated Mr. Hall with skepticism, pushing him to explain specifically where he is headed with Kmart, the troubled chain based in Troy, Mich.

headline: DIME BANCORP APPROVES MEASURES TO BAR A TAKEOVER
abstract: Dime Bancorp Inc., parent company of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, said yesterday that its board had approved a "poison pill," a measure that can make a hostile takeover prohibitively expensive. Dime, the fifth-biggest savings institution in the United States, said it did not take the action in response to any proposed takeover. "It was designed to deter any abusive takeover tactics that might be used in the future," said James Large Jr., Dime chairman. The plan would let Dime shareholders, except a would-be acquirer, buy additional shares at a discount, diluting a hostile acquirer's stake.

headline: Drug Crackdown Is Believed to Sap Colombia's Economy
abstract: As the authorities arrest leaders of the Cali drug cartel, seize their properties, close their bank accounts and destroy cocaine-processing laboratories, the organization is facing an economic crisis that many say has affected sectors of the national economy.         In recent weeks, investigations into donations by drug traffickers to President Ernesto Samper's 1994 campaign, have caused nervousness among investors and sharp declines in the stock market. While the trends have been attributed by some to Mr. Samper's difficulties, others say the weakening of the cartel cannot be ignored as a factor. In any event, drug power and drug money seem to be the root of the uncertainty.

headline: Britain and I.R.A. Inch Closer to Peace Talks
abstract: Ranking Irish and British officials say that they are close to resolving the issue that has blocked the Northern Ireland peace effort for months -- the dispute over the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army and the scheduling of full-fledged talks.   Up to now, Britain has insisted that the I.R.A. must start disarming before full talks can begin, and Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political arm, has refused to discuss disarmament until Britain sets a date for talks.

headline: Nokia's U.S. Unit Chooses Grey
abstract: Nokia Mobile Phones in Tampa, Fla., the United States division of Nokia Oy in Helsinki, Finland, named Grey Advertising in New York to handle its domestic account, which was previously at Peak, Barr, Petralia & Biety in Tampa, Fla. The billings were estimated to be as high as $15 million. Grey, which handles advertising for Nokia in 23 countries throughout Asia and Europe, was awarded the account after a two-month review that had been narrowed to Grey and Bates USA, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., which handles advertising for Nokia in some Asian-Pacific markets.

headline: Evergreen to Buy Station
abstract: The Evergreen Media Corporation is planning to buy the country-music radio station WKLB-FM (105.7) of Boston from Fairbanks Communications Inc. for $34 million in cash. This year, Evergreen Media, the radio station owner based in Irving, has purchased or announced plans to purchase 25 radio stations, bringing its total to 36 stations. Evergreen said it expected to close the WKLB purchase in the first quarter of 1996.

headline: Machine Tool Orders Rose in September
abstract: Orders for industrial tools rose 39.4 percent in September from the previous month, the Association of Manufacturing Technology said today.   Compared with September 1994, however, total orders fell 6 percent.

headline: Bristol-Myers Deal on Clot-Dissolving Drug
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company has agreed to develop Genetics Institute Inc.'s new clot-dissolving drug and to conduct clinical studies on it, in exchange for manufacturing and marketing rights, the two companies said today.   Bristol-Myers will conduct Phase 2 clinical studies on humans for the drug, a modified form of a naturally occurring clot-dissolving protein called tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA. Bristol-Myers makes and sells a version of TPA called Activase.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Leap Resigns Miller Account
abstract: The Leap Partnership in Chicago unexpectedly resigned its Miller Brewing Company account yesterday after 18 months. The billings, on Lite Ice beer and various projects, were estimated at more than $30 million.         "I know it's unheard of for an agency to resign a piece of business like this," said George Gier, a creative partner at Leap, "but Miller doesn't fit in with our goals for next year." Though Mr. Gier declined to elaborate, he said the resignation had not been prompted by problems working with Miller or by forecasts that Miller might spend less to advertise Lite Ice in 1996. And Leap was "absolutely not" interested in another brewer's account, he added.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE PLANNING TO ELIMINATE 225 JOBS
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 110 jobs at its headquarters in Pittsburgh and eliminate 115 jobs at its science and technology research center in Churchill, Pa. The cuts will eliminate 16 percent of the 670 jobs at the company's headquarters before the end of the year under a reorganization plan based on a three-month study by Arthur Andersen Consulting. In addition, about 170 employees in Pittsburgh will be transferred to other offices, leaving a staff of 390 people, a spokesman said. The cuts at the science and research center will affect about 13 percent of the center's 890 employees.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $61 million of notes due in 1996 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 5.63 percent and are priced at par. * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $45 million of debentures due in 1998 through Bear, Stearns & Co. The debentures, which are callable quarterly beginning Jan. 26, 1996, carry an interest rate of 6.46 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Farewell to a Mill That Shaped the Modern City
abstract: The George Washington Bridge came from here. So did the basic structure of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the Chase Manhattan Building, Madison Square Garden, the Metropolitan Opera House and the Time & Life Building.   All were built from steel made and shaped at the Bethlehem Steel Company's mill here on the banks of the Lehigh River. In fact, the single-piece H-shaped girder -- the building block of skyscrapers -- was first produced here in an early 20th-century financial gamble for technology that was as daring for its time as the latest silicon chip plants are today.

headline: Business Travel; Executives are scouting opportunities in Cuba these days, despite the problems of getting there.
abstract: CUBA is a potentially profitable market that is not emerging, thanks to the American economic embargo. Even so, executives or foreign representatives of American companies are scouting it like crazy these days, mostly flying there through Canada, the Bahamas, Mexico -- and even directly from the United States.  For those who want to go there, a good starting point is the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a nonprofit organization discreetly supported by major American companies, which has its headquarters in New York at 30 Rockefeller Plaza; the telephone number is (212) 246-1444. "Last year some 500 American business people visited Cuba," said John S. Kavulich 2d, the group's president, who commutes to Havana once or twice a month, "but it's double that number this year."

headline: Blockbuster's Asia Plans
abstract: Blockbuster Entertainment International, a unit of Viacom Inc., said today that it planned to open 1,000 stores in Asia by 2000. Blockbuster, the largest United States video rental retailer, said it planned to open 142 video stores in Asia through December 1996 to bring its total to 250. It also plans to expand its new music store concept in Asia with the addition of eight stores by the end of next year. Blockbuster operates 4,000 stores in the United States.

headline: Another Bomb Near Metro Hurts 12
abstract: A homemade bomb planted in a trash can slightly injured 12 people today in southern Paris. The explosion occurred near a subway station with the same name as the Lyons suburb where, a week ago, security forces shot dead a 24-year-old Algerian suspected of directing Islamic terrorist bombings.   The Algerian, Khalid Kelkal, a key suspect in planting a bomb made from a gas canister that killed 7 people and injured nearly 100 in a Paris rail station on July 25, was buried near Lyons a few hours before the latest bomb, of similar design, exploded across from Maison Blanche station. A passer-by had spotted the bomb in the trash can and called the police, but the bomb went off before they could disarm it.

headline: ORACLE SAYS IT IS DESIGNING LOW-COST COMPUTER
abstract: The Oracle Corporation said yesterday it was designing a $500 computer using chips from an Apple Computer Inc. venture. Oracle's chairman, Lawrence J. Ellison, told shareholders that the new machine would be much simpler than personal computers costing three times as much and would provide functions like electronic mail, word processing and Internet access. The Oracle computer uses the ARM chip, from Advanced RISC Machines Group, in which Apple holds a controlling stake. Mr. Ellison declined to say who would build the machines.

headline: International Briefs; Opel Seeks Polish Plant
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's German unit, Adam Opel A.G., has offered to spend 400 million marks ($280 million) to build a car factory in Poland, but formal talks have not started. An Industry Ministry spokeswoman, Beata Nawracka, said yesterday that the ministry received a letter from Opel earlier this week on plans to invest in Poland to produce about 100,000 vehicles annually beginning in 1998. G.M. has apparently lost a race to take over Poland's state-owned car maker, FSO, to the Daewoo Motor Company of South Korea. (Reuters)

headline: Executive Changes At Conde Nast
abstract: The Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications in New York is promoting a top executive and hiring another from TV Guide, effective Nov. 15.

headline: W. R. GRACE CUTS DIVIDEND BECAUSE OF UNIT SPINOFF
abstract: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had sliced its quarterly cash dividend by 64 percent because of its pending spinoff of its National Medical Care Inc. subsidiary to its shareholders. Grace, which dropped its dividend to 12.5 cents a share from 35 cents, will distribute one share of National Medical stock for each Grace share held. The spinoff is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. Grace, based in Boca Raton, Fla., also said it planned to repurchase as many as 10 million of its common shares, or about 10 percent of its stock. Grace now has about 97 million shares outstanding. Its shares closed yesterday at $66.25, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3  Stock in the Great American Backrub Store has been rising lately, but don't count on the company to work out all the kinks anytime soon. Street Smarts, by Kurt Eichenwald. INVESTING IT /Page 5  The footnotes in annual reports can be revealing or niggling, depending on who's talking, the investor or the company. By Sana Siwolop. SPENDING IT /Page 8  Though sometimes useful, living trusts are not a one-stop estate plan. By Eve Tahmincioglu. EARNING IT /Page 9  Say bye-bye to a commuter's hazards when you work from home but hello to two others: overworking and overeating. By Alice Bredin.

headline: Most Wanted; Scheduling Is All In TV Ratings
abstract: In the first week of the new television season, the top 10 list reveals the importance of scheduling, as "Caroline in the City," a new NBC series sandwiched between "E.R." and "Seinfeld," captured the No. 3 spot.   The connection between winning an Emmy award and ratings success was not as clear. "Murphy Brown" placed at No. 8, perhaps on the strength of Candice Bergen's Emmy for leading actress in a comedy series. However, "Frasier," which captured three awards -- including best comedy series -- was at No. 12. It is scheduled opposite "Home Improvement."

headline: KEVLIN TENTATIVELY AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED
abstract: The Kevlin Corporation tentatively agreed yesterday to be acquired by an undisclosed British company for $4.68 a share in cash, or $16.38 million. Kevlin said it accepted the offer because it was more than the Kaydon Corporation had offered. Kaydon, a maker of auto parts based in Clearwater, Fla., had offered to buy Kevlin for $4.50 a share, or $15.75 million. Kaydon said it ended talks with Kevlin after the higher offer was made. Company officials were not immediately available for comment. Shares of Kevlin, based in Wilmington, Mass., rose 25 cents, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

headline: CD-ROM's Are the Latest in Corporate Training
abstract: Many workdays at noontime, Holly Grady sits at the computer in the employee lunchroom at the Fred Meyer discount superstore here, munching a homemade sandwich and tapping a touchscreen.   While some of her colleagues catch up on a soap opera, Ms. Grady is learning new techniques and product information that she will put to use once her meal break is over and she is back on the sales floor.

headline: MAXTOR CONSIDERS NEW TAKEOVER BID BY HYUNDAI
abstract: The Maxtor Corporation said yesterday that it was considering a new takeover proposal by the Hyundai Electronics Industries Company, which on Sunday raised its bid to acquire Maxtor to $6.15 a share. Last week Maxtor, a maker of computer disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., turned down an unsolicited bid by Hyundai of $5.15 a share, or about $273 million, for the Maxtor shares it did not already own. Maxtor officials were not available for comment on the new bid, but an estimate based on the number of shares for the first offer valued the offer at about $326 million. Maxtor said Hyundai, based in South Korea, is its largest shareholder with a roughly 37 percent stake. Maxtor's stock rose 43.8 cents, to $5.25, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: South Africa Orders Arrest Of Ex-Officers
abstract: Government officials said tonight that arrest warrants had been issued for South Africa's former Defense Minister, Gen. Magnus Malan, and 10 other high-ranking military officers in connection with the slaying of 13 people in 1987.   General Malan oversaw South Africa's armed forces for nearly 11 years and was still in office in 1991 when it came to light that President F. W. de Klerk's National Party Government had been secretly financing a rival of President Mandela's African National Congress, the Zulu-based black political group Inkatha.

headline: International Briefs; Boddington Shares Rise
abstract: Shares of Boddington Group P.L.C., an owner of British pubs, surged yesterday after it said it might receive a bid substantially higher than its current stock price. Boddington said it had been approached by another company and that a bid might result. Traders said there was speculation that Whitbread P.L.C. was a possible buyer, although Greenalls Group was also mentioned. After the announcement, Boddington shares climbed 86 pence, or 32 percent, to 358 pence in London trading. (Reuters)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER INTERNATIONAL PLANS $500 MILLION BUYBACK
abstract: Baxter International Inc., the provider of medical supplies, said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $500 million worth of common shares in the next several years. The company, which is based in Deefield, Ill., has about 272 million shares outstanding. The stock closed yesterday at $38.625, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company also said William B. Graham had retired as senior chairman and had resigned from the board, effective on Nov. 25. Mr. Graham, who is 84, joined Baxter in 1945 and was chief executive from 1953 to 1980. He had been senior chairman since 1985.

headline: Nationalist Winds Blow Hot in the Highlands, Warming Scots to Separation
abstract: Michael Payne, a guide who knows just where to sink the hook to land a trout in a lake in the Highlands, peered off into the early morning Scottish mist while he pondered the question of independence from England.   Then he made his pronouncement: "We've got all the resources up here, oil, gas, salmon, whisky. England takes from us and doesn't give us anything back. We'd be better off without them."

headline: Rightists in Latvia Gain
abstract: A fringe party led by an expatriate with links to the German far right came in second in Latvia's parliamentary elections, partial results showed today.  Center-right parties did not do as well as expected in the weekend vote and may have difficulty forming a coalition government.

headline: VIEWPOINT; The Morals of Marketing Simpson
abstract: TO what extent is it ethical for a corporation to involve itself with O.J. Simpson?  As the Simpson case moves from the courtroom to the marketplace, this question arises with some urgency because a cascade of dubious marketing may be about to descend.  Recent press reports indicate that Mr. Simpson's advisers have plans for a $10 million pay-TV special and hope to receive a multimillion-dollar advance for his next book (in which he will explain "what really happened"). Smaller companies have already experienced a surging demand for O.J. memorabilia: T-shirts, posters, sports equipment and autographs. Alas, notoriety sells.

headline: Castro at Lunch: The Usual Fare
abstract: As other visiting heads of state and government hobnobbed with one another yesterday, President Fidel Castro of Cuba, Communist stalwart, made the rounds in New York City, meeting with the likes of David Rockefeller on Park Avenue and a group of Puerto Rican businessmen in the South Bronx.   Inside an elegant walnut-paneled room yesterday afternoon, Mr. Castro, looking a touch weary, addressed 60 people at the Council on Foreign Relations on Park Avenue. He drew quite a crowd: Tom Brokaw, Leonard Lauder, Robert Wright, Mortimer Zuckerman, Roone Arledge, Larry Tisch, Ted Sorenson, Arthur Schlesinger.

headline: International Briefs; India Venture Set
abstract: The General Instrument Corporation and the HCL Corporation of India said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to manufacture and sell broadband telecommunications equipment in India. The companies said they would initially invest $25 million in the venture. It will start up early next year with manufacturing operations expected to begin by the end of 1996. The venture will provide set-top devices for televisions that will allow consumers to increase the number of channels they receive. (Reuters)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.25   5.25   4.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.65   4.71        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.31   5.29   4.92        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.32   5.33   5.34        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.09   6.06   7.64        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.44   6.42   7.86        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.39   7.36   8.72        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.98   5.99   6.65       *Estimated daily average, source Telerate **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CONAGRA INC., Omaha, said it had sold its Omaha Vaccine Company to KHR Ltd., under its strategy to divest itself of noncore operations and focus on its food business. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Radio Stock Offering
abstract: The Chancellor Corporation, a Dallas-based operator of radio stations that was formed by the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., plans to make an initial public offering of stock. According to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chancellor plans to offer common shares valued up to a total of $201.25 million.

headline: What Makes Trump Tick?
abstract: To the Editor:         I was appalled that you published Donald Trump's paean to himself, his property and his ego as a column, rather than as a paid ad. It is not news that  Mr. Trump is shamelessly in love with himself, but do you share this infatuation?

headline: RUSSELL SHARES DROP 10% ON PROFIT ESTIMATE
abstract: The shares of the Russell Corporation fell 10 percent yesterday, a day after the company, an athletic-wear maker, said its report on third-quarter earnings would be 50 percent below the comparable period a year earlier. Russell, based in Alexander City, Ala., said sales would be up 5 percent for the period, but its profit margins had been hurt by competitive pricing pressures and higher costs for raw materials. In the quarter a year earlier, Russell earned $24.2 million, or 60 cents a share, on sales of $317.1 million. Russell's shares were down $2.75, to $23.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Cains Food Is Sold
abstract: The Dutch food and beverage company Koninklijke Bolswessanen N.V. said today that it had sold its Cains Food unit to an investor, Denis Keaveny. Terms were not disclosed. Cains, based in Ayer, Mass., produces and markets mayonnaise, dressings and pickles. The company has annual sales of about $60 million.

headline: SHARES OF CYRIX GAIN AS MICROPROCESSOR IS INTRODUCED
abstract: Shares of the Cyrix Corporation climbed yesterday after the company introduced its next-generation microprocessor, as the company scrambles to get out of the dwindling market for older 486 chips. Cyrix stock was up $2.75, at $42.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 3.3 million shares. The new chip, which had been code-named the M1 and is now the 6x86, is meant to compete with the Intel Corporation's Pentium chip and the successor to that chip, the Pentium Pro. The chip will cost about $450, which Cyrix said would be about 10 percent lower than comparable chips from Intel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Unisys to Take a Charge And Cut Jobs in a Revamping  Unisys said it would reorganize into three separate units and eliminate an undisclosed number of jobs to cut costs, taking a fourth-quarter charge that could be in excess of $400 million.   The company, struggling to transform itself from a hardware manufacturer into a computer services company, would divide into a hardware division and two service units, one specializing in systems integration and managing the information systems of other companies, the other focusing on computer and network maintenance.  [ Page 36. ] Archer-Daniels Executive Dismissed  The head of Archer-Daniels-Midland's division in Mexico, Reinhard M. Richter, has been dismissed after an internal investigation into financial transactions involving certain corporate officers. He is the fourth Archer- Daniels officer to be dismissed or forced out since last month after allegations of wrongdoing at the company.  [ 36. ] Boeing Machinists on Strike  The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, representing 31 percent of Boeing's work force, went on strike after voting down a new three-year contract offer with 78 percent opposed, but company officials said production would not be seriously affected. Shares of Boeing have drifted down about 10 percent in the last week in anticipation of the strike, but closed up 75 cents yesterday.  [ 8. ] Rhone-Poulenc Misses Stock Target  Rhone-Poulenc Rorer continued to buy shares of Fisons on the market, but failed to increase its stake in the British drug maker to the level that under British law, would have allowed it to continue to make such purchases.  [ 37. ] Eurotunnel Seeking New Bank Deal  Eurotunnel, in severe financial trouble, said it hoped to agree with its banks on a reorganization of its finances by the end of January.  [ 37. ] Daiwa Tells of '93 Deception  Daiwa Bank says American and Japanese regulators knew about deceptive dealings at its New York office as early as 1993.  [ 37. ] Consumer Borrowing Up $9 Billion  The Federal Reserve said consumer borrowing rose $9.1 billion in August after an $8.8 billion increase in July. Revolving or credit-card debt ballooned by $4.33 billion at a 13.8 percent annual rate in August, compared with a $3.25 billion expansion in July.  [ 36. ] Stocks End Mixed  Stock prices were mixed, while some technology issues, including Intel and Computer Associates, made a modest recovery. The Dow industrials rose 6.50 points, to 4,769.21. The S.& P. 500 index fell 0.14 point, to 582.49, and the Nasdaq index fell 2.16 points, to 1,012.04. For the week, the Dow fell 19.87 points.  [ 39. ] The dollar rose to 100.54 Japanese yen from 99.58 yen on Thursday and to 1.4220 marks from 1.4205 marks.  [ 34. ] Treasury bond prices were little changed, with the yield on the 30-year issue remaining at 6.42 percent.  [ 38. ] Nursing Home Rules May Be Eased  Budget bills in Congress would repeal tough Federal standards for the quality of care in nursing homes, even though the industry says it has not sought wholesale elimination of the standards. Under the proposals, states would set and enforce their own standards, which could be much less stringent.  [ 1. ] The Trabant Makes a Comeback  The Trabant, the car that was once the principal mode of transportation in East Germany and later became despised as representing everything wrong with the Communist system, has developed a cult following. The last 444 new Trabants go on sale next week at the equivalent of $13,600 each, nearly 20 times the original price.  [ 4. ] Coffee Prices Decline  Coffee prices fell in New York on signs that a recent agreement by producers to hold back exports may be falling apart. Coffee for December delivery fell 5.4 cents, to $1.181 a pound.  [ 34. ]

headline: GRAND MET NAMES A NEW CHIEF, ENDING SUCCESSION BATTLE
abstract: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said yesterday that it had named John McGrath, chairman of its spirits division, as its next chief executive, ending a long battle of succession at the London-based food and beverage company. Mr. McGrath, 57, was chosen ahead of his counterpart, David P. Nash, chairman and chief executive of the food division, which includes Burger King and Pillsbury. Mr. Nash will resign from the company on Jan. 31 and relinquish his position on its board immediately, Grand Met said. George Bull, Grand Met's current chief executive, will succeed Sir Allen J. G. Sheppard as chairman when he retires on March 1 at the mandatory age of 62.

headline: Giuliani Shares a Victory
abstract: It sounded very much like another of the upbeat announcements the Giuliani administration often makes when a company agrees to stay in New York in exchange for a break in taxes or rent. There was even more fanfare than usual, in fact, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that his administration had succeeded in keeping Unicef in New York for the next 31 years.   "Our success in keeping this vital agency and its many employees is indicative of our commitment to preserve and support key elements of the U.N. community," the Mayor told a news conference.

headline: Los Angeles Times to Revive Its Edition for East Coast
abstract: The Los Angeles Times will resume publication of its Washington edition, which was discontinued during the company's cost-cutting drive last summer, the editor of The Los Angeles Times said last night.   The Washington edition had a circulation of only about 3,000 but its closing became a symbol to many of the paper's journalists, especially those who feared the paper would no longer have a voice in national debates. Some said the move showed a cavalier attitude toward journalism by Mark H. Willes, the new chief executive of the paper's parent, the Times Mirror Company. Mr. Willes began his tenure in the summer with a series of sharp cost-cutting moves that included closing New York Newsday.

headline: Many Bids for 2 Stations
abstract: Park Communications Inc. said today that it had gotten more than 18 offers to acquire WPAT-AM and WPAT-FM, its radio stations in the New York City market. Park, based here, said it expected to negotiate a final deal within a few days.

headline: EARNING IT; Overworking? Overeating? Telecommuting?
abstract: A FEW years ago, the lights were often on at 3 A.M. in Garret Sheldon's home office. There were plenty of computer chores to do, and lots of calls from clients traveling in Asia. But even those long weeknight hours were not enough to keep Mr. Sheldon from working weekends, too -- to complete projects, to talk to clients and to meet with the other members of the Potomac Group, his information-technology and management consulting firm in Arlington, Mass.  Mr. Sheldon soon realized, however, that his business had taken over his life. So he set out to change his work habits. He still offers 24-hour availability to clients, but only for limited times, and he charges extra for it.  He and the other members of the Potomac Group are also trying to avoid communicating with each other on weekends or at night.

headline: Petrie Retail In Filing for Chapter 11
abstract: Petrie Retail Inc., a privately held women's apparel retailer formed last December by an investor group from the retail operations of the Petrie Stores Corporation, sought protection yesterday from its creditors in a bankruptcy-law filing.    The voluntary filing, made in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, followed weeks of rumors that the company was teetering on the brink.    In a statement announcing the filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, Petrie Retail said it had obtained a two-year, $115 million credit line from Chemical Bank. If the court approves, these funds would allow the company "to meet future inventory needs and to fulfill obligations associated with operating its business," Petrie Retail said.

headline: PARTNERSHIP WITH CYGNUS ENDED BY PROCTER & GAMBLE
abstract: Cygnus Inc. said yesterday that the Procter & Gamble Company, the consumer products giant, had ended a partnership between the two companies to develop and market anti-smoking products, like nicotine patches. Cygnus, which makes drug-delivery and diagnostic systems, did not indicate a reason for Procter & Gamble's decision, and said it was unexpected. The companies started the collaboration in February 1994. Cygnus already makes the Nicotrol nicotine patch, which works through the skin, but the Procter & Gamble partnership was for the development of additional patches. Cygnus, based in Redwood City, Calif., said it would seek a new marketing collaboration.

headline: New Executive at MCA
abstract: Continuing to rebuild its executive ranks, MCA Inc. announced today that it had hired Deborah S. Rosen as senior vice president in charge of the entertainment conglomerate's corporate communications and public affairs. Ms. Rosen, 39, will report to MCA's president, Ron Meyer.

headline: SINGER TO REPURCHASE UP TO 10% OF ITS SHARES
abstract: The Singer Company said yesterday that it planned to repurchase up to 10 percent of its 50.6 million common shares. Singer, a maker of sewing machines and other durable consumer goods, said it would buy the shares from time to time on the open market or in private transactions. Singer said it was buying the shares because it believed its stock was undervalued and because it was a means of increasing the company's value to shareholders. Singer shares closed at $23, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; U.S. and Russia at Odds Over Caspian Oil
abstract: The Clinton Administration, citing protection of American interests, has sought to counter Russian influence in the oil-rich Caspian Sea by fighting two projects that are being promoted by Moscow.  Much of the American involvement on the Caspian has involved trying to break a Russian stranglehold on energy pipelines from the region to Western markets.

headline: SAP Profit Falls 47% In First Nine Months
abstract: SAP A.G., Europe's largest wholesaler of computer software, said yesterday that its operating profit rose a lower-than-expected 47 percent in the first nine months of 1995 as new competition slowed growth. Operating profit rose to 385 million marks ($273 million) from 262 million marks ($186 million) in the corresponding period a year ago. Sales rose 57 percent, to 1.79 billion marks ($1.27 billion), up from 1.14 billion marks ($808 million) in the period a year ago.

headline: Maidenform Puts Account in Review
abstract: Maidenform Inc. and Ogilvy & Mather New York said yesterday that they had agreed to end their relationship after three and a half years. As a result, the account for Maidenform lingerie and other intimate apparel, with billings estimated at $2 million to $3 million, has been placed in review.   "We're proud of what we've accomplished together and how Ogilvy & Mather has helped us," said Susan Malinowski, vice president for marketing at Maidenform in New York. "Our needs are changing, however, and this seems like a logical time to seek out a smaller agency." To help manage the review, Ms. Malinowski said that the company has hired the Advertising Agency Register in New York, adding that a decision is expected by Jan. 1.

headline: Compuserve's Internet Service
abstract: Compuserve Inc. announced a service today that links computer owners directly to the Internet, stepping up competition in the Internet-access market.   Customers will be able to make a local call to dial up the worldwide network without going through the Compuserve service. The new service, Spryte, will be available at the end of the year.
