headline: Time Warner Entertainment Co. reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Werner Enterprises Inc.(WERN,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Zilog Inc.(ZLG,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Oct 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Norwest Corp.(NOB,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sep 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CNB Bancshares Inc.(CNBE,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tandy Corp.(TAN,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Total System Services Inc.(TSS,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Raychem Corp.(RYC,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Union Pacific Corp.(UNP,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Learning Accepts New Offer From Broderbund Software
abstract: The Learning Company accepted a sweetened merger offer from Broderbund Software Inc. today and rejected a competing offer from Softkey International Inc. But it was still not clear which bidder will prevail.         Under the revised terms, Broderbund's offer is valued at $555 million, representing a 13 percent increase from the previous offer. Broderbund would pay 0.92 of a share of its common for each share of the Learning Company, valuing the Learning shares at $59.685, based on Broderbund's closing price today.

headline: Atlanta Fed Chooses No. 2 To Be Its Chief
abstract: The Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank today named Jack Guynn, its vice president and chief operating officer, to be its president and chief executive. The appointment ends a months-long search after the current president, Robert P. Forrestal, announced his retirement.         At a news conference where his appointment was announced, Mr. Guynn, 52, said the Fed's top priority must be fighting inflation. He added that while inflation had slowed during the last 15 years, it should be slowed further.

headline: Ousted G.M. Head Takes New Post
abstract: Robert C. Stempel, who was ousted as chairman of the General Motors Corporation three years ago, was named chairman today of Energy Conversion Devices Inc.         Energy Conversion, a battery and high-technology materials company, also said Mr. Stempel would join its senior management as executive director. In that position, he will become involved in all aspects of the company's business, including electric vehicle batteries.

headline: In U.S. Peacekeeper Arsenal, Weapons Honed for Bosnia
abstract: The 20,000 American troops who roll into Bosnia in the days and weeks ahead will be armed with an array of advanced technology and tactics tailored for the  Balkan mission, from speedier U-2 spy plane pictures to stealthy anti-sniper teams to tanks specially equipped for blowing up land mines, American military officials say.         Some equipment has never been used in an actual mission, like a new camera on the Apache attack helicopter that will transmit aerial photographs of the cease-fire zone to a command post within 90 seconds. And proven tactics will be  adjusted for the Bosnia mission. Psychological-operation troops, for example, will prepare leaflets, radio broadcasts and posters in Serbo-Croatian advising residents that the NATO force comes in peace but will indeed defend itself.

headline: Michelin U.S. Unit Agrees to Add $380 Million to 8 Pension Plans
abstract: Michelin North America said yesterday that it would pay $380 million to the eight pension plans of its Uniroyal Goodrich Tire unit in one of the largest settlements with the Federal agency that guarantees pensions.         The pension plans, which lacked the minimum cushion of funds required under Federal law, were inherited by Compagnie Generale des Etablissements Michelin, the French tire maker, when it acquired the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company in 1990.

headline: Lebanese Rebels Fire Rockets Over Northern Israeli Border
abstract: Muslim guerrillas of the Party of God fired salvos of Katyusha rockets into northern Israel today, wounding several Israelis and raising tensions at a time  when Israel and Syria seemed to be exchanging new peace feelers.         The attacks also threatened to undermine a two-year-old agreement between Israel and the Party of God not to strike at each other's population centers around the 9-mile-wide buffer zone in southern Lebanon controlled by Israel and  its client Lebanese force, the South Lebanese Army.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sale Agreement Is Reached On Canary Wharf Complex
abstract: An investor group led by the Canadian developer Paul Reichmann and Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has agreed to buy the giant Canary Wharf office  complex here from the banks that own it, Lloyds Bank announced late today.         Mr. Reichmann built Canary Wharf in the 1980's, only to lose it in 1992 to its bank lenders, in a move that helped push his Olympia & York Development Ltd. into bankruptcy proceedings. His group is offering about L800 million, or about  $1.27 billion, for the property, a person familiar with the agreement said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * WUSA-TV, Washington, owned by the Gannett Co., to Earle Palmer Brown, Bethesda, Md., to handle its account, previously at Capital Media Inc., Rockville, Md. The billings were not disclosed. * Department of Tourism for the Dominican Republic, Santo Domingo, to the Levinson Group/Stephen L. Geller Inc., New York and Greenwich, Conn., as the first agency to handle its worldwide account. The billings were not disclosed.

headline: Georgians Vote for President and Parliament
abstract: Georgians, their country riddled by ethnic strife, voted in large numbers today for a Parliament and a President who they hope will lead them to peace and prosperity.         "I think that this day will decide the fate of Georgia," Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the leading contender, said after he cast his ballot at a polling  station in central Tbilisi.

headline: Icahn and LeBow Seek a Spinoff of Nabisco Food Unit
abstract: Announcing that they now jointly own 4.8 percent of the RJR Nabisco Holdings  Corporation, Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that they would ask the company's shareholders to demand an immediate spinoff of the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, completely splitting the company's food business from its  tobacco operations.         In a day punctuated by charge and counter-charge from the challengers and the company, Mr. LeBow, chairman and chief executive of the Brooke Group Ltd., asserted in an interview that "we are not interested in taking control of the company." He added: "Do the spinoff, and Carl and I will go away."

headline: Blaze in India Kills Over 300, Mostly Youths
abstract: At least 310 people, more than half of them schoolchildren, were burned or trampled to death today when a tent erected for a school ceremony in a small northern Indian town caught fire, setting off a stampede in a walled courtyard,  the police said.         About 350 others were injured, many in critical condition with extensive burns, a police spokesmen said.

headline: A Rail Union That Could
abstract: The hope was that Paris and the rest of France would limp back to normal this week after a paralyzing national rail strike and a struggle between public-sector labor unions and the Government over austerity measures to reduce  the federal deficit.         But after three weeks in which many hundreds of thousands marched to support  the strikers, it seems clear that it will take a long time to heal the wounds.

headline: Market Place;Nokia drops a bombshell, and pays for it on Wall Street.
abstract: THERE may be any number of hot conference calls today, but none is likely to  be hotter than the discussion officials of Nokia are scheduled to hold with a bunch of irate investors and analysts.         Wall Street is upset with Nokia, Finland's largest publicly held company and  the world's second-largest cellular phone maker after Motorola, because it feels it has been sandbagged.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Says the Dutch Must Help Save Fokker
abstract: Daimler-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it would not bail out its Netherlands-based Fokker aircraft unit unless the Dutch Government also contributed to a rescue effort. Fokker needs an estimated 2.3 billion guilders ($1.45 billion) in financial aid and is being kept afloat by short-term loans from Daimler.          The Dutch Government, which owns 22 percent of the holding company that controls Fokker, said that if it contributed at all to a rescue effort, it would do so only in proportion to the stake it holds. The main responsibility for Fokker's rescue lies with Daimler-Benz, said Luuc van Zijp, a spokesman for  the Economics Ministry in The Hague.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Uncapping New Ideas For U.S. Oil;Teamwork in the Fields Helps Industry Rebound
abstract: For most of his 30 years as a field worker in the huge Kern River oilfield of Texaco Inc., Charley Johnson had to go through a chain of managers before beginning repairs on any one of the 4,700 wells. Often, it would take him days to bring a malfunctioning well back to peak production.         Today, those delays are a thing of the past. "Now I determine that a pump is  going bad and start the work on my own," said Mr. Johnson, who maintains production of 36 wells. If he needs backup or advice, he decides for himself which of the 349 workers and managers at the oilfield, the nation's fifth largest, to call on his two-way radio.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Liz Claiborne Names Two New Agencies
abstract: Liz Claiborne Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had named two agencies, Gotham Inc. and Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot, to handle separate portions of its account.         Gotham, based in New York, was awarded the creative portion of the Liz Claiborne and Elisabeth apparel and accessories account. Gotham, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, was given that assignment after a two-month review that had been narrowed to Gotham and three other finalists, all based in  New York: Angotti, Thomas, Hedge; Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, and Wells Rich  Greene BDDP, part of BDDP Worldwide.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Alvin Chereskin, a longtime force in beauty advertising, gives up retirement for Fresh Carats.
abstract: AN agency creative executive who dominated beauty and fashion advertising for more than three decades before retiring a year ago is back at work.         Alvin Chereskin, the linchpin of the Estee Lauder account at AC& R Advertising, where he served in capacities including chairman, chief executive and executive creative director, is opening an advertising and marketing consulting company in New York with clients that include the designer Vera Wang.

headline: A 2d S.E.C. Official Quits
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the departure today of its general counsel, Simon Lorne. The S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., said there was no connection between the departures of Mr. Lorne and Brandon Becker, former head of the agency's market regulation division, who resigned on Tuesday.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Search to Intensify For Some Barings Assets
abstract: Authorities have stepped up efforts to locate the lost assets of the defunct  Singapore futures operations of Barings P.L.C., obtaining a court order to interrogate six former executives of the failed British merchant bank. The search for the assets by the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse had so far focused on the jailed trader Nicholas W. Leeson, who has been blamed for the $1.38 billion collapse of Barings in February. Armed with a High Court order obtained this week, Price Waterhouse will try to force the former executives to  appear in court for questioning, the firm's lawyer said yesterday.          Price Waterhouse will try to get three of the executives who are out of Singapore -- Peter Norris, Michael Kilian and Roy Johnson -- to return to answer questions. The other officials who will be questioned are Simon Jones, James Bax and Fu Ya Yin, the lawyer said. All three live in Singapore. Also yesterday, a spokeswoman for Mr. Leeson's lawyer said that Mr. Leeson had decided not to appeal his 6-year prison sentence for his conviction on charges related to the fall of Barings.   (AP)

headline: Dow Continues to Surge, But Broad Market Is Flat
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average continued its remarkable surge yesterday, while the broad stock market remained relatively flat.         "The day's story was that the economically sensitive stocks rose," said Barbara G. Marcin, vice president of Citibank Global Asset Management. "And the  Dow is made up of 30 economically sensitive stocks."

headline: Ohio Mortgage Bank Settles Discrimination Complaint
abstract: The Justice Department extended its campaign against racial discrimination in the banking industry today, reaching a $420,000 settlement with a big Ohio lender accused of charging higher fees to black applicants for mortgages than to white applicants.         The Huntington Mortgage Company, a unit of Huntington Bancshares Inc., agreed to pay the money in response to a Justice Department complaint -- filed along with the settlement today -- that the company had charged higher fees to 117 black applicants in the Cleveland area than to white applicants. The fees consisted mainly of points, which are payments made by mortgage applicants when  their loans are approved and which are typically equal to 1 to 3 percentage points of the balance of the mortgage.

headline: Reserve Board Cuts Key Rate; Markets Climb
abstract: Nudged along by a slowing economy and nervous financial markets, the Federal  Reserve lowered a key interest rate today by a quarter of a point.         The cut in short-term rates, which the Federal Reserve said was justified because of the lack of any threat of inflation, allowed the stock and bond markets to regain some of their big losses on Monday. But it left considerable uncertainty about whether Wall Street would be cheered by President Clinton's agreement with Republican Congressional leaders this afternoon to come up with a framework for a budget accord that would be concluded by the end of the year. The announcement at the White House came after the markets closed.

headline: Chrysler's Chief Strongly Attacks Kerkorian
abstract: In a strong personal attack, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation denounced Kirk Kerkorian yesterday as an uninformed troublemaker whose pursuit of profit was harming other stockholders.         The unusually strong criticism by Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of the No. 3 auto maker, was the first time that he had formally -- and publicly -- attacked Mr. Kerkorian by name as well as the motives and impact of his long-running attempt to assert greater control over the direction  of the company.

headline: Looks Like Landslide for Aristide's Choice
abstract: Rene Preval, handpicked to succeed President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, appeared today to be well on his way to the landslide victory expected of him, as the first unconfirmed and unofficial results from the vote on Sunday began trickling in.         An official tally is not expected until Dec. 27, but people close to Mr. Preval's campaign said early figures showed him with more than four times as many votes as the nearest of his 13 competitors, a percentage even higher than Mr. Aristide received in 1990. But the dimensions of the victory may have been diminished by a low voter turnout.

headline: Cobra Golf In Agreement On Takeover
abstract: Cobra Golf Inc., a maker of premium clubs, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by American Brands Inc. for $700 million.         Cobra's stock jumped on the news, gaining $7.875, to $35.50 in afternoon trading on the Nasdaq market, just under American Brands' $36-a-share offer. American Brands was off $2.25 at $44.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Loses Claim Against 2 Railroads
abstract: Eurotunnel, the cash-short operator of the tunnel from Britain to France, lost a financial case late on Tuesday against railway companies. The International Chamber of Commerce in Paris rejected a L2.3 billion ($3.62 billion) claim against French and British rail companies brought by Eurotunnel.  The ruling is a fresh setback to the troubled tunnel operator, which badly needs cash to help repay L8 billion ($12.60 billion) of commercial bank debt.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Thousands Rally in Cairo For Victims of Bombing
abstract: Thousands of Egyptians shouted anti-terrorist slogans today as they marched in a funeral procession for victims of the suicide bombing of the country's embassy in Pakistan on Sunday.         The display included representatives from all of Egypt's opposition parties,  and it was intended to underscore the widespread revulsion felt here after the attack, which is believed to have been carried out by Muslim militants.

headline: Nash Finch-Hackney Pact
abstract: The Nash Finch Company has agreed to sell its two North Carolina convenience  store wholesale subsidiaries to the H. T. Hackney Company of Knoxville, Tenn. Terms were not disclosed. Nash Finch, a Minneapolis-based food wholesaler, said  the two operations together have annual revenues of about $300 million. The units are the Thomas & Howard Company of Newton and T&H Service Merchandisers Inc. of Hickory.

headline: Payrolls Rose By 121,000 In September
abstract: Factory employment resumed its decline in September, but the economy generated enough service jobs to swell overall payrolls by 121,000, Labor Department figures showed today.         The unemployment rate, meanwhile, remained at 5.6 percent, about where it has hovered for a year.

headline: Deng's Economic Drive Leaves Vast Regions of China Behind
abstract: Chen Xianhe is not a revolutionary. He is just a down-on-his-luck peasant whose wife has run away to escape the poverty here and whose only cow fell off a cliff in May and died.         But Mr. Chen, 30, and many of his neighbors in this remote and desperately poor region of southwestern China, speak a language of disaffection that is worrying China's Communist Party leaders.

headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL;The Death of Rabin: An On-Line Report
abstract: A special report on the Rabin assassination with news updates, as well as articles and photos from the archives of The New York Times, is available to computer users on         Clyde Haberman, former Jerusalem bureau chief of The Times, will answer questions from the public about the Middle East outlook in a live interview on

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bagel Chain Selects Fallon
abstract: Progressive Bagel Concepts Inc., a retail bagel chain based in Golden, Colo., said yesterday that it had named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis as the first agency to handle advertising for its Einste!n Bros. retail bagel stores. The billings have not been determined. Gary Gerdemann, a spokesman for Progressive Bagel, said Fallon McElligott was awarded the account after an informal review in which the other participants were not disclosed. Progressive Bagel owns and operates 57 stores in 7 states including California, Colorado and Florida, and plans to open 275 to 300 stores by the end of 1996. The company has a loan from  Boston Chicken Inc. that can be converted into a majority equity stake in Progressive Bagel.

headline: Haitian Ex-Paramilitary Leader Confirms C.I.A. Relationship
abstract: The former leader of Haiti's most feared right-wing paramilitary group has confirmed that he was a paid agent of the Central Intelligence Agency from 1991  to 1994.         The former paramilitary leader, Emmanuel Constant, now jailed in a Maryland detention center on immigration charges, said published reports linking him to the C.I.A. were true. He made his admission in a videotaped interview to be broadcast on Sunday on the CBS News program "60 Minutes," which provided transcripts to other news organizations.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Money Market Funds Jump $113 Billion This Year
abstract: ASSETS in money market funds have really surged this year, suggesting the category will hit $1 trillion by February 1998, said Money Market Insight, a newsletter in Ashland, Mass.         So far this year, the funds have added $113 billion, reaching $732 billion last week. The category grew by $43 billion for all of 1994.

headline: Edna Deane, Dancer And Inspiration, 90
abstract: Edna Deane, the world champion ballroom dancer famous for being the girl "who's danced with the Prince of Wales," died on Wednesday at her home in Rottingdean, on the English Channel, The Times of London reported today. She was 90.         Miss Deane was born Edna Morton Sewell in the Orange Free State, now part of  South Africa, in 1905 to British parents. In 1907, her family returned to England, where she trained in ballet and ballroom dancing.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BALLY ENTERTAINMENT SETS HEALTH-CLUB UNIT'S SPINOFF
abstract: The Bally Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it planned to issue about 11.8 million shares of the Bally's Health and Tennis Corporation in a spinoff of the unit, which has been losing money. Bally Entertainment, a Chicago-based casino company, said it planned to issue one share in the unit for every four Bally Entertainment shares held by stockholders of record Nov. 15. There are 47.2 million shares outstanding. The distribution is to occur by Jan. 5. Bally Entertainment has been working on the spinoff for more than a year. Bally's Health owns about 330 fitness clubs in the United States and Canada, while Bally Entertainment owns casinos in Nevada, New Jersey, Louisiana  and Mississippi.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DETAILS PROVIDED ON PLAN FOR GLOBAL SPORTS NETWORK
abstract: The News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, and Tele-Communications Inc.  said yesterday that they had formed an alliance to obtain sports programming and televise it worldwide. As expected, the News Corporation, which owns the Fox network, and Tele-Communications, which is based in Englewood, Colo., will each  own 50 percent of the venture. Each company will contribute TV channels and sports-programming rights to the venture. The partners said the assets were valued at more than $2 billion. Under the arrangement, the News Corporation has  agreed to pay $300 million in cash to the Liberty Media Corporation, the programming arm of Tele-Communications, said Chase Carey, the chairman and chief executive of Fox Television. The News Corporation is based in Sydney, Australia.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Racal Electronics Buying British Rail Phone Unit
abstract: The military and communications company Racal Electronics P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay L133 million ($204 million) for British Rail's national telephone network. British Rail Telecommunications, which reported a pretax profit last year of L17.6 million ($27 million), was put up for sale in May as part of the privatization of Britain's rail network. Its communications network will give Racal a data link passing through most major British cities along British Rail tracks.          Racal, which supplies the electronic terminals for the British lottery, also reported that its pretax profit jumped 28 percent, to L30.1 million ($46 million), in the six months that ended on Sept. 30 and that revenue rose 5 percent, to L505.6 million ($776 million).   (Reuters)

headline: U.S. Markets Closed
abstract: All markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. Banks and government offices are also closed. But most markets overseas are open. Tomorrow, the stock and bond markets and the Chicago commodity markets will be open but will end trading in the early afternoon; the  New York commodity markets will be closed.

headline: Coca-Cola Project For Cliff Freeman
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company has broadened its agency roster by naming Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York to handle an undisclosed project. The company also said yesterday that it would award an additional assignment to a shop already on its roster, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore.   Bob Bertini, a spokesman for Coca-Cola in Atlanta, confirmed reports of the assignments this week in Adweek. He said that Freeman, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was added to the Coca-Cola roster without a review, but declined to discuss the nature of its assignment. Adweek reported that the assignment could involve advertising for a two-liter plastic contoured bottle.

headline: Iron Men With Clay Feet
abstract: To the Editor:   The heralding of people who don't take vacations or time off, show up sick, put work before life's events -- like graduations, births and deaths -- and foist their ethic on others and claim themselves superior is not only sad, it is outright perverse in today's employment market ("Baseball's Iron Men Aren't the Only Ones Made of Sterner Stuff," Earning It, Sept. 17). They are not made of sterner stuff, they are at best strange, at worst boorish menaces to decent human values. JOSEPH H. SADOVE Manhattan, Sept. 17 The writer is a principal consultant for the Oracle Corporation.

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 201.97 points, or 1.12 percent, at 18,157.33. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 59.39 points.

headline: 4 Slain at Mexican Service
abstract: With a spray of gunfire that interrupted a memorial service inside a cemetery, four people were killed today and at least seven were wounded in a village in the violence-plagued state of Guerrero, officials there said.    The deaths bring to 75 the total of gangland-style killings since June in Guerrero, an agricultural state. The Governor, Ruben Figueroa Alcocer, has faced rising criticism for failing to improve security in the state.

headline: International Briefs; SGS-Thomson Shares Soar on Profit Gain
abstract: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's largest independent chip maker, saw its shares soar 14 percent in French trading after it reported a 48 percent gain in third-quarter net profit to $129 million. The company's shares were up $2.75, at $45.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. SGS-Thomson, which last year sold a 17 percent stake to investors in New York and Paris, reported earnings of $87.3 million in the third quarter a year earlier.

headline: DELPHI FINANCIAL GROUP TO ACQUIRE SIG HOLDINGS
abstract: Delphi Financial Group Inc. will acquire SIG Holdings Inc., a provider of workers' compensation insurance, for at least $175 million. Delphi Financial, which underwrites life, disability and personal accident insurance through its Reliance Standard Life Insurance unit, said late on Thursday that it would exchange 4.4 million shares, valued at roughly $75 million, and $55.5 million in cash for SIG. Delphi will also assume $45 million of SIG's debt. Delphi, based in Wilmington, Del., could make an added payment of as much as $20 million if SIG meets certain earnings objectives. SIG provides insurance through its Safety National Casualty unit, which is based in St. Louis. Delphi's stock rose $2.25 yesterday, to $20.25 a share, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: BOMB RIPS TRAIN UNDERNEATH PARIS, WITH 29 WOUNDED
abstract: Another terrorist bomb ripped open an underground commuter train early this morning, wounding 29 people and forcing France to confront a serious and continuing domestic threat from political convulsions in its former colony of Algeria.   French authorities viewed the attack, in which five people were seriously wounded, as the eighth one carried out or attempted in the last three months by Islamic militants who are protesting France's ties to the military Government in Algeria.

headline: U.S. and U.N. Aides Open Talks On Policing a Peace in Bosnia
abstract: Americans working on plans to replace the United Nations force in Bosnia with a United States-led NATO operation met today with United Nations officials to discuss leaving some experienced troops from NATO countries in the area.   Among those likely to remain if NATO polices a peace settlement are rapid-reaction forces from Britain and France, who are only nominally under United Nations command. But American officials hope to keep other soldiers on the ground, too, so that a NATO operation, involving perhaps 50,000 troops, can begin quickly after a cease-fire. Up to half the troops could be American.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Settles With F.T.C.
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission in Washington said yesterday that it had reached a settlement with the Johnson & Johnson Consumer Products subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson Inc. over claims in print advertisements last year for K-Y Plus spermicidal lubricant that the commission had challenged.

headline: International Briefs; Siemens to Buy Unit Of British Company
abstract: Siemens A.G., the multinational German electronics company, has agreed to buy 75 percent of a telecommunications equipment unit of Mercury Communication Ltd., Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, Mercury's parent, said yesterday. The unit's net asset value is around $:50 million ($79 million) and Siemens will pay a small premium for its stake, said John Docherty, director of investor relations at Cable and Wireless.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merger Mania Nears Record-Setting Pace The wave of corporate consolidations is likely to set a record this year. The pace is as feverish as it was in the last three years of the 1980's, the decade of the takeover.

headline: JOHNSON CONTROLS AGREES TO BUY ROTH FRERES
abstract: Johnson Controls Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in Roth Freres S.A., a French auto-interior maker, for about $175 million to $200 million. Johnson Controls would own 75 percent of Roth Freres, which expects 1995 sales of $600 million. The deal is expected to close in late November. Johnson Controls, based in Milwaukee, makes automotive seating, interiors and batteries. The companies have been joint-venture partners since 1988.

headline: International Briefs; British Pub Chains In $821.6 Million Tie
abstract: A British pub operator, Greenalls Group, agreed yesterday to acquire the Boddington Group in a transaction valuing Boddington at $:518 million, or $821.6 million. Greenalls will pay $:20 in cash and 17 shares for every 25 shares of Boddington, also a pub operator.

headline: 150 Die as Jet From Miami Crashes in Colombia; 7 Survivors Found
abstract: About 150 people, many of them Colombians coming home for the holidays, were  killed Wednesday night when an American Airlines 757 traveling from Miami to Cali crashed in a remote, mountainous area 50 miles north of here.        Debris from the crash was scattered widely, and officials initially said all  164 people on board had been killed. But today rescue workers found at least seven survivors, including a family of four who lived in New Jersey, and said they expected to find other survivors in the rubble as the search continued.

headline: Rebel Attacks Disrupt Chechen Vote
abstract: An early round of Russian parliamentary elections was severely disrupted today by fierce rebel attacks in two major Chechen towns, and federal troops seemed to suffer severe casualties in each of them.         The fighting broke out only days after the leader of the Chechen secessionists, Gen. Dzhokar M. Dudayev, promised not to interfere with the voting.

headline: A New Safety Net Is Created For Homeowners in Quakes
abstract: California took a big step yesterday toward overhauling its homeowners' earthquake insurance market to create a new financial safety net for homeowners, replacing insurance companies.         After a heated competition among 40 securities firms, the state said firms led byMorgan Stanley & Company would handle an innovative $1.5 billion bond sale that would be part of a $10.5 billion package to pay homeowners' claims.

headline: Sony and Visa Team Up to Offer Entertainment Service on Internet
abstract: The Sony Corporation of America said yesterday that it had formed a strategic alliance with Visa U.S.A. to create a global information and entertainment center on the Internet's World Wide Web.         Computer users who connect to the Sony Station site next spring will be able  to preview and discuss music CD's, television programs and films, shop for Sony  products and play interactive games with other Internet users, said Matt Rothman, a vice president at Sony of America, a unit of the Sony Corporation of  Japan.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;VALUE HEALTH PLANS TO ACQUIRE MEDINTELL SYSTEMS
abstract: Value Health Inc., a provider of managed health care, said yesterday that it  would acquire the Medintell Systems Corporation, which markets a pharmacy information management system for hospitals. Value Health will issue about one million shares of common stock to finance the purchase of Medintell, a privately held company based in Minneapolis. The shares of Value Health rose $2.125 yesterday, to $28.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, so the deal would be worth about $28 million at yesterday's closing price. Medintell, founded in 1993, has exclusive licenses for certain software from the Mayo Clinic to develop pharmacy management products. Value Health is based in Avon, Conn.

headline: Stock Prices Turn Upward On Latest Economic Data
abstract: Stock prices rebounded yesterday after Thursday's selloff, following a Commerce Department report that the gross domestic product grew at a surprisingly high 4.2 percent annual rate in the third quarter.         The stock market opened lower, mimicking the bond market, which typically reacts bearishly to positive economic numbers, fearing the Federal Reserve will  not reduce interest rates further. But as the day wore on, the major stock indexes turned around and closed at or near their day's highs.

headline: British-I.R.A. Talks Break Off, and Sinn Fein's Leader Looks toWashington
abstract: Talks between British officials and political representatives of the Irish Republican Army broke off inconclusively today.         Afterward Gerry Adams, the I.R.A. political leader, said he would go to Washington to confer with top American officials before President Clinton visits Britain and Ireland later this month.

headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: AMERICAN JEWS;Leaders Lay Politics Aside To Mourn Death of Rabin
abstract: Across the political spectrum, whether they embrace Israel's peace talks with the Palestinians or deplore them, horrified leaders of American Jewish groups bowed their heads last night in mourning for the assassinated Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin.         For many, the shock was magnified beyond measure by the fact that the killer  was a Jew.

headline: Mexico Woos U.S. Mexicans, Proposing Dual Nationality
abstract: The Government is campaigning hard for an amendment to the Mexican Consitution that would allow Mexicans living in the United States to retain Mexican nationality rights even when they adopt American citizenship.         The double nationality amendment, as it is known, aims to remove legal hindrances that have discouraged Mexicans living legally in the United States, estimated to number two million to three million, from naturalizing and registering as voters there, officials said.

headline: Pearson-MAI TV Team Wins British License
abstract: A group led by Pearson P.L.C. and MAI P.L.C. won the license for Britain's fifth nonsatellite television network yesterday and vowed to woo viewers with alternative programs.  Channel 5 is expected to begin broadcasting in autumn 1996 and to reach up to 70 percent of the population.

headline: GILBERT ASSOCIATES TO PAY $30 MILLION FOR XEL STOCK
abstract: Gilbert Associates Inc. of Reading, Pa., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy all of the XEL Corporation's common stock for $30 million in cash. Gilbert, which owns the GAI-Tronics Corporation, a supplier of industrial communications equipment, would pay XEL shareholders more if XEL, which makes computer network products, meets earnings targets in the fourth quarters of 1996, 1997 and 1998, and meets revenue targets from 1996 until 1998. Gilbert Associates said it would use the proceeds from its recent sale of its Gilbert/Commonwealth unit to the Parsons Corporation for the purchase of XEL, a closely held company based in Aurora, Colo.

headline: AMR AGREES TO CONTRACT WITH BAGGAGE HANDLERS
abstract: The AMR Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a tentative contract agreement last week with baggage handlers, who voted down a six-year contract in late September. The contract must be ratified by about 14,000 baggage handlers and ramp workers, who voted against the contract because of concerns about seniority. The ratification vote is scheduled for later this month. The contract is part of a plan by AMR to cut $1 billion in expenses. The remaining 13,000 Transport Workers Union members ratified the contract. "We did reach what we felt was a satisfactory conclusion," said Ed Koziatek, chief negotiator for the Transport Workers Union.

headline: Burden of Strikes Increases but France Bends Just a Bit
abstract: A wave of strikes that has paralyzed much of France swept into a third week today as miners fought with the police in the east of the country and the Government abandoned a position of unyielding aloofness by opening negotiations  with striking rail workers.         There was no immediate sign of a breakthrough, and it appeared certain that the strikes -- staged to protest France's attempts to streamline its overburdened state sector, trim social programs and cut chronic budget deficits  -- would continue at least until Tuesday, when labor unions are planning demonstrations.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Sterling Multimedia Computers, New York, to Korey Kay & Partners, New York, to handle its account, previously handled in-house. The billings were estimated at $8 million. * Eggland's Best Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle the creative portion of its account, previously handled by N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York. The media portion remains at Western International Media, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. The billings were not disclosed.

headline: DREYFUS PRESIDENT TO RESIGN AFTER 10 MONTHS
abstract: Robert E. Riley plans to resign as president and chief operating officer of the Dreyfus Corporation, the mutual fund unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation, just 10 months after taking the job. Mr. Riley, 65, has been named president and chief executive at Leggat McCall Properties, a closely held commercial real estate company based in Boston, Mellon said yesterday. Mr. Riley will be succeeded by Christopher M. Condron, vice chairman of Mellon Bank, as of Nov. 30. Mr. Condron will supervise Mellon's investment management subsidiaries which, with Dreyfus, oversee about $200 billion in assets.

headline: S.E.C. Notice Sent to Lehman
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has informed Lehman Brothers that the agency plans to bring an enforcement action against the firm in connection with the sale of Denver International Airport bonds, Reuters reported yesterday.    The firm, the lead underwriter in a $257 million airport revenue bond and a senior manager in many other airport bond offerings, received a "Wells" notice from the S.E.C.'s Denver office. Such a notice is a warning that the regulatory agency will bring an enforcement action against the firm unless Lehman can provide a compelling reason to stop it.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Daiwa's Fate: Merger Partner Or Lesser Bank?
abstract: Toshihide Iguchi, the 44-year-old trader at the Daiwa Bank who is charged with the bank's disastrous $1.1 billion loss, may wind up having a hand in creating the world's largest bank. The Sumitomo Bank, one of the world's largest, has raised the prospect of a merger with Daiwa that could create a banking behemoth with assets of 87.7 trillion yen, or roughly $860 billion.         But with potential resistance coming from Daiwa's largest shareholder, the Nomura Securities Company, or from some other quarter, another line of thinking  is that Mr. Iguchi's messy bond trading scandal may turn Daiwa into a much smaller institution. The pressing questions now for Daiwa are these: Can Daiwa thrive on its own? Does it want to suffer the humiliation of becoming a lesser institution?

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RJR NABISCO URGES SHAREHOLDERS TO REJECT 'GAMBLE'
abstract: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation is urging shareholders to reject a proposal for an immediate spinoff of its Nabisco food subsidiary, calling the move a "high-stakes gamble." In letter to shareholders mailed yesterday, the New York-based maker of Camel and Winston cigarettes said an immediate spinoff of its remaining 80.5 percent stake in the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the cookie and cracker unit, would undermine shareholder value and entangle the company in litigation. The letter from RJR's chief executive, Charles M. Harper, also castigated the financiers Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, who on Monday began soliciting shareholder votes and promised a proxy fight for control of the company if RJR delayed the spinoff.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bolivian Power Sale
abstract: The Bolivian Power Company said yesterday that it would sell certain assets to the Spanish electric utility Iberdrola S.A. and an affiliate for $65.3 million. The Bolivian electric utility will sell two distribution units to Iberdrola for $62.3 million. The units distribute electricity to the Bolivian cities of La Paz and Oruro.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Political and Energy Crises Foil Ecuador's Hopes
abstract: This was supposed to be Ecuador's year.         An austerity program curbed inflation and stabilized the economy, and the country was looking forward to the rewards of sacrifice: increased employment, rebuilt roads and bridges, and foreign investment in the Government-run oil, electrical and communications industries.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bozell Worldwide Gets Nynex Mobile
abstract: Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile said yesterday that it had named Bozell Worldwide  in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $50 million. The account was previously divided among four agencies: the Baltimore office of W. B. Doner & Company; Erwin-Penland in Greenville, S.C.; Mason & Madison in New Haven, and the New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, which is owned by the WPP Group.          Jim Gerace, a spokesman for Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile in Bedminster, N.J.,  said that Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, was awarded the account after a two-month review in which the other participants were not disclosed; Adweek reported that the review had been narrowed to two finalists, Bozell and Doner. Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile is a joint venture of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation.

headline: A Bozell Office Gets New Owners
abstract: Two top executives of the Washington office of Bozell Worldwide along with an executive of Pitney Bowes Inc. have acquired that Bozell office and renamed it Laughlin, Marinaccio & Owens. The terms were not disclosed.

headline: CORDIS ASKS DELAY ON JOHNSON & JOHNSON OFFER
abstract: The Cordis Corporation urged shareholders yesterday not to make any decision about Johnson & Johnson's unsolicited $1.6 billion tender offer until it had reviewed the proposal. Cordis said it would consider the offer "in due course" and would announce a decision no later than Nov. 2. Johnson & Johnson announced the offer on Thursday, noting that the Miami-based maker of medical devices to treat heart disease had rebuffed its advances.

headline: HAFSLUND NYCOMED SHARES GAIN ON MERGER TALKS
abstract: American depository receipts for shares of Hafslund Nycomed A.S. rose 2.3 percent yesterday amid speculation that the Norwegian pharmaceuticals company may merge with the Ivax Corporation. Hafslund Nycomed, which is based in Norway, refused to comment on the report. "As a matter of principle we have no comment on any rumors connected with Hafslund Nycomed," Eric Cameron, its head of corporate communications, said. The A.D.R.'s of Hafslund, each equal to one class B share, rose 75 cents, to $27.625, a 52-week high. Shares of Ivax closed unchanged at $29.75, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: DART GROUP IN PACT WITH ITS FORMER PRESIDENT
abstract: The Dart Group said yesterday that it had reached a settlement with Ronald Haft, its former president, that will end at least some of the disputes among the feuding Haft family. Under the terms of the settlement, Mr. Haft will step down from his posts at Dart and its Crown Books and Trak Auto units. He will also sell all of his interest in the company to Dart or third parties. Mr. Haft will also drop a lawsuit against his father, Herbert, that had been part of his battle to wrest control of the company from its aging founder. "I'm hopeful that if not the end, this is the beginning of the end of the Haft family feud as it relates to Dart," said Larry Schafran, chairman of the board's executive committee. The settlement is subject to approval by a judge, the company, based in Landover, Md., said.

headline: ZENITH NATIONAL DROPS PLAN FOR MANAGED-CARE VENTURE
abstract: The Zenith National Insurance Corporation said yesterday that it had dropped plans to develop a managed-care company with U.S. Healthcare Inc. and the Unum Corporation because it could not reach terms with U.S. Healthcare. The venture had intended to market regular managed health care coverage in a package with workers' compensation and disability insurance coverage. U.S. Healthcare, based in Blue Bell, Pa., is a managed-care company. The other two companies are insurance providers. Zenith National, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., said it would expand an alliance with Unum in California and other areas. Unum is based in Portland, Me.

headline: Yeltsin's Foreign Minister Stays in Office, Forlornly
abstract: If on the eve of a major foreign trip President Clinton told reporters that he was sick of his Secretary of State, the denouement would be fairly predictable: Warren Christopher would huffily resign, and Mr. Clinton would appoint someone else.   When the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, told reporters on Thursday that he wanted to dismiss his longtime Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, Mr. Kozyrev did not respond or resign. And at the airport on his way to Paris this morning, Mr. Yeltsin seemed to regret his public tirade, or at least its timing. He said that what he meant was that Mr. Kozyrev needed a strong deputy to restore discipline to the Foreign Ministry.

headline: A Patent Falsehood
abstract: To the Editor:   Laura Pederson's article about inventing and patenting gadgets concludes with a repetition of the apocryphal story about the head of the patent office recommending in 1899 that the office be closed because "everything that could be invented had been invented" ("Invented a Gadget? Don't Quit Your Job," Minding Your Business, Sept. 10). Although this tale serves as a marvelous example of some men's shortsightedness, it's time to stop repeating it as fact.

headline: International Briefs; A Danish Revamping
abstract: The Danish shipping company Burmeister & Wain Holding agreed yesterday on a restructuring plan with United States and Danish creditors. B.& W. said in a statement that the proposal called for creditors and bondholders to swap their loans for new equity in the company. B.& W. went into receivership in June after it nearly ran out of cash and reported a 1994 net loss of 902 million crowns ($163.4 million) on sales of 1.75 billion crowns ($317 million). In receivership, a company is supervised by a court-appointed manager. (Reuters)

headline: Japanese May Close Mortgage Company
abstract: Seven major Japanese commercial banks may close an indebted home mortgage company they own and write off billions of dollars in loans, a spokesman for one of the banks said today.   The spokesman, at the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said the possibility was being discussed but that no decision had been made. The financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported this morning that the banks had decided to close the mortgage company, Housing Loan Service, with each bank writing off 80 percent of its loans -- a total of about 280 billion yen, or $2.8 billion -- to it.

headline: Morrison Knudsen To Shed Transit Unit
abstract: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation has created a separate company out of its transit car manufacturing unit and transferred ownership to a group of insurance companies.   The new company will be called the American Passenger Rail Car Company, or Amerail, for short. It will be based in Chicago with 1,800 employees, said Brent Brandon, a Morrison Knudsen spokesman.

headline: HAYES SET TO EMERGE FROM CHAPTER 11
abstract: Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. plans to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy as an independent company. Hayes said yesterday that it would recapitalize through equity investments and new credit lines. Under the plan, Northern Telecom Ltd. and ACMA Ltd., a Singapore venture-capital firm, will together acquire 49 percent of Hayes. Dennis C. Hayes, the company's chairman, and the Hayes employee stock plan will own the remaining 51 percent. Hayes requested that the bankruptcy court schedule a confirmation date for its plan as soon as possible. Since Hayes filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy last November, it has attracted a number of potential suitors, including the U.S. Robotics Corporation, Diamond Multimedia Systems Inc. and Boca Research Inc.

headline: People
abstract: Gordon Bowen was named an executive vice president and group creative director on the AT&T International account at Young & Rubicam New York. Mr. Bowen, who had been a creative consultant to Y.& R. New York, previously worked on the Coca-Cola account at McCann-Erickson New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., and on the American Express account at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of the WPP Group.

headline: Gilbert Acquires XEL
abstract: Gilbert Associates Inc. said today that it had acquired the XEL Corporation for $30 million in cash. Gilbert may also make additional payments for the company, a maker of telecommunications equipment in Aurora, Colo., based on XEL's projected earnings.

headline: ASPECT TELECOMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY TCS
abstract: The Aspect Telecommunications Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the TCS Management Group Inc. subsidiary of Next P.L.C., the British retailer and financial services concern, for $37.5 million. TCS, based in Nashville, supplies software to manage telephone centers, like those operated by the utilities and customer-service industries. The payment will involve $33 million in cash and a $4.5 million promissory note, said Aspect, which provides products and services for call centers. Aspect, based in San Jose, Calif., said TCS would be an independent unit of the company.

headline: International Briefs; Russia to Sell Oil Stake
abstract: The Russian Government will sell a 51 percent stake in Sidanko, the country's third-largest oil producer, on Dec. 7, an official said yesterday. The Government will auction the entire stake with a starting price of $125 million, said Igor Plotnikov, spokesman for the State Property Committee, which is handling the sale. Only Russian companies and joint ventures in which foreign participation is limited to 25 percent will be welcome to bid. Sidanko officials are unhappy with the decision. They want to sell four equal stakes of 12.5 percent to strategic investors. (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Wolfgang Puck Narrows Review
abstract: The Wolfgang Puck Food Company has narrowed the review on its account, previously handled by Kresser Stein Robaire in Santa Monica, Calif., to four finalists. The billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

headline: International Business; Lloyds Bank to Merge With TSB Group
abstract: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. and TSB Group P.L.C., a rival bank, have agreed to merge, creating Britain's largest retail bank, with assets of $:150 billion, or $238 billion. Over all, Lloyds-TSB would be the fourth-largest bank on the stock exchange in terms of assets.   "It's the deal of the year as it seems everyone wins all around," Mike Trippitt, a banking analyst with SBC-Warburg, said.

headline: I.B.M. Names 2 To Fill Vacancy At Top of Lotus
abstract: I.B.M. moved swiftly today to control any damage caused by the resignation of Jim P. Manzi as chief of the Lotus Development Corporation, naming two vice presidents to lead the recently acquired software company.   The resignation of Mr. Manzi on Wednesday -- 99 days after Lotus became an I.B.M. subsidiary -- had been expected to lead to an exodus of top Lotus executives. And indeed there was one resignation today, by Robert K. Weiler, a senior vice president of desktop business group.

headline: Simplifying the Tax Code Isn't So Simple
abstract: Proposals to overhaul the Federal income tax system share two stated goals: to make the tax code simpler and fairer. But the debate in Washington, and among taxpayers across the country, shows the complexities of making such changes. Peter Passell's look at the proposals ("The Tax Code Heads Into the Operating Room," Sept. 3) drew many reader reactions, including various responses to its discussion of plans for a so-called flat tax. To the Editor:   The comprehensive article seriously understates the taxes that would have to be paid with the flat tax. The understatement is particularly severe for those with very low incomes and for middle-income taxpayers with incomes as high as $100,000. The very rich, however, would have huge reductions in their taxes.

headline: German Role in Balkan Unit
abstract: Germany would send as many as 5,000 soldiers to join a NATO force in the Balkans to enforce a Bosnian peace agreement but remains reluctant to deploy its troops in Bosnia itself, officials here said today.   The development, which could deepen Germany's involvement in a part of the world scarred by Nazi invasion, was announced as NATO delegates in Brussels began discussing plans for the proposed peacekeeping force, which would include some 25,000 American soldiers out of 60,000.

headline: Index of Leading Indicators Rose in August
abstract: The index of leading economic indicators rose in August, the Commerce Department said today, indicating moderate expansion in the months ahead.         The index, which is intended to project economic growth over the next six months, increased two-tenths of 1 percent in August, in contrast to a decline of the same amount in July. The increase in August was only the second this year.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.25   5.25   4.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.76   4.76        3-MO. headline: An Abitibi-Price Buyback
abstract: Abitibi-Price Inc. said today that it had completed the repurchase of 10 percent, or about 8.7 million, of its common shares. The company, a forest products concern, said it had bought the shares at an average price of $22.30 a share, at a total cost of $194 million. Abitibi-Price, based here, said the buyback reduced the number of its common shares on a fully diluted basis to 90.9 million.

headline: Communications Bill Opens Up New Rift
abstract: Supporters of a sweeping telecommunications bill scrambled to smooth over yet another apparent rift among Republican lawmakers, this one over a provision that Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, attacked as a multibillion-dollar "giveaway" to broadcasters.         Senator Dole's comment was but a brief remark in a news conference Thursday on the budget battle in Washington. But it threatened to reopen a policy battle  of Bosnian complexity, which at least one Republican senator feared could scuttle the communications bill.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The imitation of Southwest by several no-frills airlines may be the highest form of flattery.
abstract: FIRST the Flintstones, then Captain Valu, and now Marge, Homer and Bart Simpson. Is this any way to promote an airline?   Well, yes, if you're an upstart regional carrier hoping to distinguish yourself from the pack. A couple of new airlines say they are taking their cue from Southwest Airlines, which has had its flight attendants singing to the tune of the Flintstones and other familiar melodies since its inception in 1971.

headline: Western Group Further Reduces Russian Role in Azerbaijani Oil
abstract: Western oil companies, in what appeared to be a further blow to Moscow, seemed today to marginalize Russia as a likely main route for the huge quantities of crude oil expected from this Asian republic in the next century.  Members of an American-dominated consortium and Azerbaijani leaders said most oil from a $7.4 billion venture would probably reach the market through a Turkish Mediterranean port, Ceyhan.

headline: L'Oreal Earnings Rise
abstract: L'Oreal, the world's largest cosmetics company, reported yesterday that its first-half profit rose 5.5 percent, which was at the bottom end of expectations. The company, which makes of Lancome and Helena Rubinstein cosmetics, Cacharel perfumes and Vichy skin creams, reported a profit of 2.75 billion French francs, or $551 million, compared with 2.61 billion francs a earlier. The company said sales for the first nine months rose 15.3 percent, to 39.7 billion francs, from the year-earlier period. (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Channel One Names Merkley Newman
abstract: The Channel One Network, which broadcasts a daily sponsored newscast in classrooms around the country, said yesterday that it had named Merkley Newman Harty in New York to handle its account, which had previously been inactive. The billings were estimated at under $2 million.         Merkley Newman, a unit of the

headline: Czechs Get $140 Million From Stratton Venture
abstract: Michael D. Dingman, who won a reputation for building industrial conglomerates in the United States, has invested $140 million in Czech industrial companies and plans to install new managers to increase competitiveness.

headline: CSS INDUSTRIES TO BUY UNIT OF GIBSON GREETINGS
abstract: CSS Industries signed an agreement yesterday to buy Cleo Inc., the gift-wrap unit of Gibson Greetings Inc., for about $128.5 million in cash and short-term notes. CSS Industries, a maker of printed paper products based in Philadelphia, said the purchase price was substantially below Cleo's net book value. CSS Industries said it expected to complete the deal by Nov. 15. Cleo, based in Memphis, had revenue of $189 million and a pretax loss of $37 million last year.

headline: Clinton Signs Order Easing Travel, Aid and Money Transfers Between U.S. and Cuba
abstract: President Clinton has signed an executive order that would ease restrictions on travel to Cuba by Cuban-Americans, academics, artists and members of the clergy, and allow American relief agencies and human rights groups to greatly expand their work in Cuba, Administration officials said today.   In a speech on Friday, Mr. Clinton also plans to announce measures that would allow American and Cuban undergraduates to study in each others' countries and American news organizations to open bureaus in Cuba, the officials said. Mr. Clinton signed an executive order instituting the changes on Tuesday as part of a broad new effort to increase the flow of democratic ideas into Cuba, they added.

headline: Business Travel; Fees for guests who check out of their rooms early may become standard for the hotel industry.
abstract: CORPORATE travel departments are not going to like it, but Westin and Hyatt hotels have decided to charge guests who check out one or more days ahead of schedule.    Hyatt's policy, with a $50 fee limit, is expected to be in effect by the end of the year at all 103 of its hotels in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean, a Hyatt spokeswoman said, and is already in effect at some properties, including those in Denver; Kansas City, Mo.; Milwaukee; Minneapolis; New Orleans, and Orlando, Fla., as well as the Grand Hyatt Washington.

headline: Teleglobe Canada Talks of China Project
abstract: Teleglobe Canada Inc. and a Chinese telecommunications company are negotiating a $500 million project to build the first fiber optic link between China and North America, to carry voice, video and data communications.   Teleglobe Canada, an international telecommunications carrier based in Montreal, said today that it was negotiating with the Lian-Tong Communications Corporation, which operates one of China's two national communications networks.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $25 million of bonds due in 2005 through Salomon Brothers. The noncallable issue is priced at par to yield 6.23 percent.   * West Texas Utilities Co., Abilene, Tex., a unit of Central and South West Corp., is selling $80 million of first-mortgage bonds due in 2005 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The bonds are priced at 99.483 to yield 6.447 percent. The noncallable issue is rated A1 by Moody's, A+ by S.& P. and AA- by Duff & Phelps.

headline: People
abstract: * Jeffrey Burch was named publisher at House Beautiful magazine, New York, a unit of the Hearst Corp., succeeding Adrienne Cleere, who resigned after four months. Mr. Burch was previously associate publisher at Cosmopolitan magazine, New York, also owned by Hearst. At Cosmopolitan, Jennifer Gallo was named to succeed Mr. Burch. She was previously advertising director at Esquire magazine, New York, also owned by Hearst. And at Esquire, Susan Plagemann, its advertising manager, was promoted to succeed Ms. Gallo. * Peter Lenahan was named to the new position of publisher at Historic Traveler magazine, Stamford, Conn., owned by Cowles Media Inc. He was previously president at Sales Concepts Associates, New York.

headline: Spelling Trouble
abstract: Bad spelling may not be an absolute bar to success -- remember a recent Vice President and his "potatoe"? -- but thoughts of the same politician suggest it won't make you appear any smarter, either. Nevertheless, botched spellings are a bigger and bigger blight at the office, spreading from day-to-day letters to legal contracts, resumes, product packages and other more formal precincts. If you have a story about bad spelling in the business world, send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: LASERVISION CENTERS IN PACT WITH SUMMIT TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Laservision Centers Inc., which operates laser systems for correcting nearsightedness, agreed yesterday to buy 15 Excimer laser systems from Summit Technology Inc. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Summit Technology received F.D.A. approval on Oct. 20 to market its Excimer laser for treating low to moderate myopia. Laservision's six United States centers will begin operating as soon as surgeon training and installation of upgraded software are completed, it said. The St. Louis-based company has said it plans to open up to 50 Excimer laser centers in the next 12 months.

headline: Sybase Data Base Software Might Aid in a Turnaround
abstract: When Sybase Inc. introduces the newest version of its most important software product today, it hopes to silence its critics and stem the competitive pounding it has taken for much of the last year.   Its rivals, the Oracle Systems Corporation and the Informix Corporation, have been asserting for months that Sybase was unable to adapt to more powerful computers using multiple processors. Sybase's shares fell 40.6 percent between the beginning of the year and early October, and its earnings have slipped. Earlier this month, Sybase, based in Emeryville, Calif., said third-quarter earnings plunged to 2 cents a share from 31 cents a year ago, while revenues were up only 7 percent.

headline: Bonds Slip After Data On Payrolls
abstract: Treasury prices slipped yesterday as traders and investors took profits after recent gains.         The lackluster showing followed a report on employment in October that failed to give the market a clear indication of the direction of the economy and of interest rates. The employment report, which showed a weaker-than-expected increase in the number of new jobs, echoed the market's view that economic growth was slowing. But it did not provide a compelling case for the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates anytime soon.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ For companies facing complex legal issues, Cal Crary is on the case. By Anthony Ramirez.

headline: CYPRUS AMAX TRANSFERRING A RUSSIAN GOLD PROJECT
abstract: The Cyprus Amax Minerals Company plans to transfer ownership of a Russian gold project to its 51 percent-owned Amax Gold Inc. unit in exchange for stock that would raise its stake in the company to 58 percent. The Denver-based companies expect the transaction, valued at $95 million, to be completed in two phases by 1997, when the Kubaka mine in far eastern Siberia is scheduled to begin production. The Russian unit, the Cyprus Magadan Gold Corporation, owns a 50 percent interest in the Omolon Gold Mining Company, which is developing the mine.

headline: A Fascination With Things American
abstract: In a Germany already flush with American influence, this banking center on the Main River is so dominated by new office buildings and English-language signs that locals often refer to it disparagingly as "Mainhattan."   When it comes to American books, however, the Germans' tenor changes.

headline: Rockefeller Bid Adds Investors
abstract: The Exor Group S.A., a holding company affiliated with the Agnelli Group of Italy, has joined Goldman, Sachs & Company, David M. Rockefeller and the New York developer Jerry I. Speyer in their bid to win control of Rockefeller Center.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Goldman group said Exor would contribute $90 million to the group's $440 million offer to buy out Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that is poised to take ownership of the center when it emerges from bankruptcy.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A table on Oct. 8 with an article about investing in multibusiness and single-business companies reflected erroneous figures supplied by the financial management advisory firm of Stern Stewart for the companies' profit margins above capital costs. A corrected version appears today on page 4.

headline: A Congressional Stand
abstract: With Bosnia peace talks in two days, the Clinton Administration was battling with the House over sending peacekeepers. Page A9.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CINCINNATI MICROWAVE SHARES SLIDE AS MUCH AS 33%
abstract: Shares of Cincinnati Microwave fell as much as 33 percent yesterday after the company said that John Noland, chief operating officer, was resigning, effective immediately. Mr. Noland left to pursue other business interests, the company said. It did not elaborate. Mr. Noland and other executives have been named in four shareholder lawsuits filed against the company, a maker of wireless communication devices, in the last two months, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Company officials could not be reached for comment.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: International Briefs; GE Capital Bids For Sovac of France
abstract: The GE Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had bid to acquire Sovac, a French consumer business credit company, for 610 francs, or about $123, a share. A GE Capital spokesman would not disclose the total amount of the offer but a French newspaper report valued the bid at 7.7 billion francs, or about $1.55 billion.

headline: Tenneco to Buy Plastics Unit From Mobil for $1.27 Billion
abstract: Striving to transform itself from a highly cyclical pipeline, chemicals and heavy equipment company into a smoothly growing manufacturer, Tenneco Inc. announced today that it would acquire the Mobil Corporation's plastics division for $1.27 billion.   Though hardly glamorous, the division has some of the industry's best-known brand names, including Baggies food sacks and Hefty trash bags.

headline: MERGER OF 2 LARGEST HOSPITAL CHAINS CLEARED
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission concluded an agreement yesterday permitting the merger of the nation's two largest hospital chains, the biggest hospital merger in United States history. The commission gave final approval to a consent agreement with the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation to insure that the company's $3 billion merger with Healthtrust Inc. would not impair competition. The merger would create a corporation with 320 hospitals and more than 100 outpatient surgery centers in 36 states, England and Switzerland. As a condition for approval, Columbia/HCA, based in Carrollton, Tex., agreed to sell seven hospitals and end a joint venture with another hospital. Details of the proposed agreement were announced in April.

headline: Northwest Gas and Electric Utilities to Merge
abstract: In an unusual combination, the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, an electric utility, will merge with the Washington Energy Company, a natural gas utility, in a stock deal valued at $488 million, the companies said yesterday.   The merger would be one of the first takeovers of a gas company by a large electric utility. Analysts said the combination would make sense because a combined company could reduce costs mainly by cutting the work force.

headline: World Bank Chief Backs Public Projects
abstract: The new president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, said today that he wanted the institution to do more to encourage private investment in developing countries, but that it would also continue to back large public projects.   He also again criticized Congress for planning sharp cuts in the United States' contribution to the International Development Association, the World Bank's agency that helps poor countries; he warned that American companies could be excluded from overseas contracts as a result.

headline: Jefferson-Pilot Buys Insurer
abstract: The Jefferson-Pilot Corporation said it had bought most of Household International's insurance unit for $575 million in cash.   The purchase of the Alexander Hamilton Life Insurance Company allows Jefferson-Pilot, a Greensboro-based life insurer that also owns radio and television stations, to almost double in size to about $14 billion in assets.

headline: Treasuries Unchanged In Optimism On Economy
abstract: Treasury prices were steady yesterday as optimism that the economy was expanding at a moderate pace returned to the market.   Bond prices fell sharply on Friday morning after a report on the gross domestic product was stronger than expected. But prices ended mixed that day, buoyed in part by optimism that a Federal budget agreement would be reached. And many in the market still expect that the Federal Reserve will again lower short-term interest rates.

headline: A Russian Role in Bosnia
abstract: The U.S. and Russia have agreed on how Russians can serve in Bosnia outside NATO command: by reporting to Americans. Page 5.

headline: CHARTER MEDICAL ACQUIRING STAKE IN GREEN SPRING
abstract: The Charter Medical Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire a majority stake in Green Spring Health Services Inc., a provider of managed-care behavioral health services, for $73.2 million in cash and stock. Charter, based in Atlanta, will buy 51 percent of Green Spring, which is based in Columbia, Md. The six Blue Cross and Blue Shield organizations that own Green Spring will continue as key customers, and will retain a 49 percent stake. Charter also said it would change its name to Magellan Health Services Inc. and would operate three primary units: Charter Behavioral Health Systems, Green Spring Health Services, and a newly created Magellan Public Solutions. Shares of Charter were up 87.5 cents, at $19.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: MANITOWOC WITHDRAWS BID FOR SHANNON GROUP
abstract: The Manitowoc Company said yesterday that it had ended its attempt to buy the Shannon Group Inc., a privately held maker of commercial refrigerators, freezers and related products. The transaction was valued at more than $100 million. Manitowoc, based in Manitowoc, Wis., which makes cranes and related products, said it could not agree on terms with Shannon. Affiliates of Trivest Inc., a private investment firm, own a majority stake in Shannon.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: 3COM CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., completed the acquisition of Chipcom Corp. Southborough, Mass., for about $900 million in stock, combining the two makers of computer-networking equipment.  ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC., New York, an insurance brokerage, bought nine retail insurance offices from Jardine Insurance Brokers Inc. Kansas City, Mo., for as much as $48 million.  KENTUCKY MEDICAL INSURANCE CO., Louisville, Ky., a medical-liability insurance concern, has reached a final agreement to be acquired by Michigan Physicians Mutual Liability Co. East Lansing, Mich., another medical-liability company, for $25.4 million. PLAID CLOTHING GROUP INC., New York, a maker of men's and boys' clothing, is seeking buyers for its Calvin Youthwear Division, a boys' clothing line, as part of its effort to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rockefeller Center Trust Delays Deal with Zell Group  Rockefeller Center Properties, the real estate investment trust that is scheduled to take ownership of Rockefeller Center, delayed its deal with an investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, while it considered two other offers made in the last week.   The trust said it would not exercise its option to require the Zell group to buy a 9.7 percent stake for $10 million. The decision signals an effort to mend fences with shareholders and creditors. Market Place.  [ Page D6. ] British Air to Evaluate Alliances  British Airways said it was evaluating its alliances in North America after the announcement by the USAir Group that it was involved in talks with the parent companies of American and United Airlines on a possible takeover. British Airways owns 24.6 percent of USAir and depends on the carrier to feed passengers to its trans-Atlantic routes. Some analysts said British Airways would begin talks with other domestic carriers.  [ D4. ]   Acquittals in Growth Hormone Case  A Minneapolis judge acquitted a Genentech sales manager and three Caremark International employees accused of paying kickbacks to a doctor for prescribing a synthetic human growth hormone.  [ D6. ] Amended Offer for Publisher  The Western Publishing Group said that Richard E. Snyder and Warburg Pincus Ventures had renegotiated their offer to buy nearly a one-third interest in Western. The amended offer appears to be for less money than the deal that was originally announced early last month.  [ D2. ] U.S. Moves on Russian Oil Deals  The Clinton Administration, citing protection of American interests, has sought to counter Russian influence in the Caspian Sea oil region by fighting two projects that are being promoted by Moscow.  [ D2. ] Rubin Predicts Global Growth  Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the world economy was in "a pause," but forecast global growth of about 2.6 percent next year and reaffirmed the Clinton Administration's commitment to a stronger dollar. On the eve of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Mr. Rubin also said there had been progress toward constructing a new "financial safety net" to prevent future Mexican-style financial disasters.  [ D3. ] Questions Over Wireless Systems  As the telecommunications industry gathers in Geneva for its quadrennial trade show, two troubled debt offerings have raised questions about the viability of so-called global wireless personal communications.  [ D4. ] A New Kind of Personal Computer  Jean-Louis Gassee, the founder of Be Inc. and the former engineering head of Apple Computer, demonstrated a new personal computer with its own operating system software.  [ D6. ] A Premium for Simpson Case Ads  Media directors and other agency media executives said they were being asked by the broadcast networks to pay $200,000 to $300,000 yesterday for a 30-second daytime commercial placed around the O. J. Simpson verdict. Ads during that time period would regularly cost from $30,000 to $35,000. But some advertisers shied away from placing ads. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.  [ D2. ]

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * The National Hockey League, New York, will promote its 79th season, which began last week, in a campaign carrying the theme "The coolest game on earth." NHL Productions, an in-house agency, created the campaign. Also, the league and the National Hockey League Players' Association are jointly introducing N.H.L. Power Play, a quarterly magazine to be produced by the Quarton Group in Troy, Mich.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ALTERNATIVE RESOURCES CORP., Lincolnshire, Ill., said Michael E. Harris had resigned as chief financial officer. Bradley K. Lamers, currently vice president of finance, was named acting chief financial officer. KENETECH CORP., San Francisco, an operator of alternative-fuel electric power plants, said Jean-Yves Dexmier, its chief financial officer, had resigned over differences with management and directors about who should handle dealings with the investment community. A successor has not yet been named.

headline: SYBASE SHARES GAIN ON PREDICTION OF REVENUE GROWTH
abstract: Shares of Sybase Inc. rose yesterday after the software company's executives told investors that they expected a coming product to sell well in the next few quarters. The rise occurred even though the company said late on Thursday that its third-quarter net income had fallen 95 percent, far more than Wall Street expected. But the company's executives said that a coming product, System 11, would fix shortcomings of the company's chief product and that they expected revenue growth to accelerate after the first quarter of next year, analysts who listened to a conference call said. Shares of Sybase, a software company based in Emeryville, Calif., were up $1.875, to $34, in Nasdaq trading of 9.1 million shares yesterday.

headline: Top Guerrilla Is Extradited To Argentina
abstract: The leader of one of Latin America's most notorious guerrilla groups was captured in Mexico City on Saturday and extradited on Sunday night to Argentina. He is wanted here for various crimes, including masterminding a 1989 assault on an army barracks in which 40 people were killed and 100 wounded.
